Robert Wilson, d. 1600(fl.1572-1600) The pleasant and Stately Morall, of the three Lords and three Ladies of London. With the great Ioy and Pompe, Solempnized at their Mariages: Commically interlaced with much honest Mirth, for pleasure and recreation, among many Morall obseruations and other important matters of due Regard. by R. W. London Printed by R. Ihones (etc.) 1590 (66) p. Preliminaries omitted. Play details The three lordes and three ladies of London. Genre: Moralities. Date first published: 1590. Date first performed: 1588-1590.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Pollicie Pompe Pleasure Wit Wealth Wil/Will Simplicity Painefull Penurie Nemo Sorrowe Love Lucre Conscience Fraud Usurie Dissimulation Simony Falshood Double Dealing Honest Industrie Pure Zeale Sinceritie Dilligence Multiple speakers Fealtie Constable Pride Ambition Tiranny Shame Treachery Terror Shealtie Desire Delight Devotion Wench (singing) London One within

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

head.stage: The pleasant and Stately Moral, of the three Lords and three Ladies of London. The Actors names. Policy, Lord of London. Pomp, Lord of London. Pleasure, Lord of London. Wit. Policy's page. Wealth. Pomp's page. Will. Pleasure's page. Nemo, a grave old man. Love, Lady of London. Lucre, Lady of London. Conscience, Lady of London. Honest Industry, Sage. Pure zeal, Sage. Sincerity, Sage. Pride, Lord of Spain. Ambition, Lord of Spain. Tyranny, Lord of Spain. Shame, Pride's page. Treachery, Ambition's page. Terror, Tyranny's page. Desire, Lord of Lincoln. Delight, Lord of Lincoln. Devotion, Lord of Lincoln. Sorrow, a Jailer. Simplicity, a poor Free man of London. Painful Penury, his wife. Diligence, a Post, or an Officer. Fealty, Herald at Arms. Shealtie, Herald at Arms. Fraud, Gallant. Usury, Gallant. Dissimulation, Gallant. Simony, Gallant. Falsehood. one that belongs to Fraud and Dissimulation. Double dealing, one that belongs to Fraud and Dissimulation.

body.stage: Enter for the Preface, a Lady very richly attyred, representing London, hauing two Angels before her, and two after her with bright Rapiers in their handes.

sp.l: Lo, Gentles, thus the Lord doth London guard,
Not for my sake, but for his own delight:
For all in vain the Sentinels watch and ward,
Except he keep the City day and night.
Now may my foes in vain both spurn and spite,
My foes I mean, that London represent,
Guarded from heaven by Angels excellent.
This blessing is not my sole benefit,
All England is, and so preserved hath been ,
Not by man's strength, his policy and wit,
But by a power and providence unseen.
Even for the love wherewith God loves our Queen:
In whom, for whom, by whom we do possess
More grace, more good, than London can express.
And that hath bred our plenty and our peace,
And they do breed the sports you come to see,
And joy it is, that I enjoy increase,
My former fruits were lovely Ladies three,
Now of three Lords to talk is London's glee.
Whose deeds I wish may to your liking frame,
For London bids you welcome to the same.

body.stage: Enter the three Lords and their pages: First, Policy with his page Wit before him, bearing a shield: the imprese, a Tortoise, the word, Prouidens securus . Next Pomp, with his page Wealth bearing his shield, the word, Glorie sauns peere : the imprese a Lily. Last, Pleasure, his page Will, his imprese, a Falcon, the word, Pour temps : Pol. attired in black, Pomp in rich robes, and Pleasure in colours.

sp.speaker: Pollicie
sp.l: Here I advance my shield and hang it up ,
To challenge him whoever dare deny,
That one of those three London Ladies rare
Ought not of right be matched with Policy:
A London Lord, the which I represent.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And pomp provides his challenge in his word,
( Glorie sauns peere ) claiming the one of them,
Not by compulsion, but by common right,
Yet maugre men my shield is here advanced
For one matchless, a London Lady best
Beseemeth Pomp (a London Lord) to have .

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Pleasure hath soared as doth his imprese show,
To look aloof on earthly Ladies all,
Yet never could my curious eye discern
A Dame of worth, for London's Pleasures love,
But one, and she doth shine as silver Dove.
Of self bred soil, of London is her race,
For whom in challenge I my shield advance.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thus each in honour of his Mistress
And in regard of his well-daring mind,
Hath here impresed the challenge of his right:
But Lordings both, and brethren bred and sworn,
A caution must be had in this conceit,
That all our thoughts aspire not to one heaven,
Nor all our ships do sail for one self haven,
I mean that all our suites and services
We tend and tender to one only Dame,
All choosing one, refusing the other two.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: A great mislike amongst us that might breed.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: I seek but one and her unto myself .

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And one wish I sans partner of my loves.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: It stands with honour to be sole or none.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Whom lovest thou pleasure?

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Hark ye.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Tush, ye lie.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: If my master were a soldier, that word would have the stab.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: well Will, still you will be a saucy Scab.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Why Pleasure? Pomp hath chosen Lucre's love.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Why pomp? But pleasure honours Lucre most.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And policy may Lady Lucre gain
Before you both: but let us not contend,
For Nemo doth the Ladies prisoners keep,
Though they were slandered late with Liberty
And marriage to three far born Foreigners.
Then first it fits we practise their release,
And see them, and by sight our liking place,
For yet we love as Gossips tell their tales,
By hearsay: Fame, not Favour hath us yet inflamed.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Lord policy with reason hath discussed
pleasure consent, and so our love shall hold.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Ye never found that London's Pleasure erred
From reason, or from pomp and policy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come on sir boy, attend you well your charge,
Wait in this place to watch and ward this shield,
If any man in honour of his love,
So hardy be with stroke of sword to attaint
This shield, and challenge him that hereby challengeth,
Say for thy Lord as should a trusty Page,
That policy doth dare him to perform
A hardier task than common challengers.
If he demand what policy may be,
A Lord of London say, one of the three.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And you (sir boy) for pomp perform the like,
Bid him that dare this imprese batter once,
Be well advised he be no beggars brat,
Nor base of courage, nor of bad conceit:
To match himself with such magnificence,
As fits Lord pomp of London for his love:
Call if he come that can encounter me,
Or move me not for each envious swad.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Will, be not wanton nor of wayward mood,
Wait as do these, use faith and diligence,
And mark him well that dare disdain this shield,
Which London's Lord that pleasure hath to name,
Hath here advanced in honour of his Dame.
I bid thee mark him well, whatever he be,
That London's pleasure doth in malice scorn,
For he is a Rascal, or a stranger born.
Good boy mark well his gesture and his look,
His eye, his gate, his weapon and attire,
And dog him to his lodging, or his den,
For I will make him scum and scorn of men,
No better boy than Will, when Will is pleased,
Be pleased my boy, and so be my good Will.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And so good boys farewell, look to your charge,
Watch well good Wit, who scorneth London's policy,
Be wary Wit, for thou canst well discern.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Wealth watch for pomp for thou canst well defend

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Will can do something too when pleaseth him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Will is a good boy where better is none.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Nay Wit were the best boy if Will were gone.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: Nay wealth is the best boy, sirs let that alone.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Iwis he saith true Will, this wealth is a gay lad,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I care not for him, curmudgeonly Swad.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: well , miss me a while and you will go near to be sad.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Will, ye are wilful, if of him ye be not glad.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Nay Wit if thou want him, thou wilt go near to be mad.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: To keep us still quiet, I would other talk we had,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I hope we will not fall out being none but we three.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: If Wealth were away, Wit and Will would agree.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Nay, Wit and will are at strife, when there is nobody but we.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Let pass, and of our shields (sirs) let us make a little glee,
Will, what gives thy master here? a Buzzard or a Kite.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Wit, you show yourself a Gentleman by guessing so right,
A Buzzard? thou Buzzard, Wit, hast no more skill
Than take a Falcon for a Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O be quiet good Will;:
It was but for sport, for I know the bird else,

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: Thou mightst see it was no Buzzard man by the bells:

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: What is the reason of this Falcon, I pray thee Will show.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Thou knowest that a Falcon soars hie, and stoops low,
So doth pleasure.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And what is the word?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Pour temps, for time.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A very pretty one, I would it were in rhyme.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: In rhyme Wit, why so?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Because it wants reason.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Look for my fist Wit, if ye rap out such treason.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Treason, to what, boy?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: To my masters bird.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Now Will my thumb wags, it was but to his word.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: It is a pleasant Gentleman, this young mast. Wit,
Your master hath something too, I pray ye what is it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Look Will, and guess.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: It is a Toad in a shell.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: I had as leave ye had said, a Frog in a well.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Is it not a great Butterfly, Will, canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What is it in sadness?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A Tortoise my boy, whose shell is so hard, that a laden cart may go over and not break it, and so she is safe within, and wheresoever she goes, she bears it on her back , needing neither other succour or shelter but her shell: the word underneath her is Prouidens securus , the provident is safe, like to the Tortoise, armed with his own defence, and defended with his own armour: in shape somewhat round, signifying compass, wherein always the provident foresee to keep themselves within their own compass, my boy.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: wittily spoken, now wealths mayst. hath got a Daffadowndilly.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.p: If Will had not been wilful, now he might have said a Lily, whose glory is without comparison, and beauty matchless, for Salomon the most sumptuous King that ever was, was never comparable in glory with the Lily, neither is there any cities matchable with the pomp of London, mistake me not good boys, that this pomp tends to pride, yet London hath enough , but my Lord pomp doth rightly represent the stately magnificence and sumptuous estate without pride or vainglory to London accommodate, and therefore the word is well applied to the imprese ( Glorie sauns peere ) for that the Lily is neither proud of the beauty, nor vainglorious of the pomp: No more is London, but if it be joyful of anything , it is of the peace and plenty, both flowing from two such fountains as becomes not us to name. Now therefore, my good boys, know that my Master is rather Magnificence than pomp in bad sense, and rather pomp than Pride in the best sense.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: And my Lord is not pleasure sprung of Voluptuousness, but of such honourable and honest kind conceit, as heaven and humanity well brooks and allows pleasure pleasing not pernicious.

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: Who would have thought that Will had been philosophous,
But what means the word pour temps in the shield, for time?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Wit, shall I call thee fool? the best pleasure of all lasts but a time,
For of all pleasures most pleasing to sight,
Methinks there is none to the Falcons hie flight,
Yet diseases end it, the breach of a wing,
Nay, the breach of a feather spoils that sweet thing:

sp.speaker: wit
sp.l: And so my master hath the vantage will ye or no,
pomp and pleasure may be ill.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: May not policy be bad?

sp.speaker: weal.
sp.l: Wit, well overtaken by Will that crafty Lad.

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: A crafty Goose, the Gander gives him health,
Bad policy is seldom found in so Christian a common wealth,
As London is I trust, where my master is a Lord.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And ours so too.

sp.speaker: wea.
sp.l: Well , let us accord, for wit is a good thing, yet may be ill applied

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: And so may wealth, be it employed in pride,
And will worst of all, when it disdains a guide.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: A Jackanapes hath wit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And so he hath will .

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: But he never hath wealth: now ye are both still.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes, he wears a chain.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Well spoke, and like a bearward.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: If ye be Non plus let the matter fall.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Wit, dost thou see? thus goes wealth away withal .

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Let us reason no further for we shall have glee,
Here is a challenger to our shields, step we aside.

body.stage: Enter Simplicity in bare black, like a poor Citizen.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: He will eat them I think, for he gapes very wide.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: Say nothing to him, and ye shall see the fool go by.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Sirrah, gape not so wide for fear of a fly.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: Fly, flame flirt: why? Can a fly do hurt?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yea, have ye not heard that the fly hath her spleen
And the Ant her gall?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: My Uncle hath so I wean, for it is an angry old fellow
When his gall runs over : children good day,
Whose pretty lads are you three?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Three, are ye sure?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I will not swear till I have told you: one, two, three.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I beshrew thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Me boy, why? I am beshrewed already, for I am married.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: Then thou hast a wife?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yea, I would thou hadst her, if thou couldst stay her tongue,

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: I thy wife man? Why, I am too young.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And I am too old, but in good earnest good boys, be not angry, that I call you boys, for ye are no men yet, ye have no beards
sp.l: And yet I have seen boys angry for being called boys:
Forsooth they would be called youths: well , yet a boy is a boy
And a youth is a youth: well , if ye be not ashamed of the boy,
Good boys, whose boys are ye?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: No whit ashamed sir of that that we are, nor ashamed at all of those whom we serve, for boys we be, and as we be, we serve the three Lords of London, to weet, policy, pomp, and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: A pretty spoken Child and of a pretty wit.

sp.speaker: Wil
sp.l: Wit is his name indeed, are ye one of his Godfathers, ye hit it so right?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: It is more than I know, then is thy name wit boy? Now of mine honesty welcome, for I have wanted thee a great while.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Welcome sir, how so? why do ye entertain me so kindly? I cannot dwell with you for I have a master already.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: So have I too, but she learns me little wit: my wife I mean Well , all this while I stand here my wares are not abroad, and so I may loose both my customers and market.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: Wares sir, have ye wares? what wares do ye sell?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly Child, I sell Ballads: soft, whose wares are these that are up already? I paid rent for my standing, and other folks wares shall be placed before mine, this is wise indeed.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O, the fineness of the wares (man) deserve to have good place.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: They are fine indeed, who sells them, can ye tell? Is he free?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Our masters be, we wait on this ware, and yet we are no chapmen.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Chapmen, no that is true, for you are no men, neither Chapmen nor chopmen, nor chipmen nor shipmen, but if ye be chappers, choppers or chippers, ye are but chapboys, and chapboys ye are double.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Double, how is it? Teach me that and you will make me laugh a little.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: And me a little:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And me a little:

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Then your three little laughs will make one great laugh:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: True, for if three fools were one fool, that were a great fool. But how are we double chapboys?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Because ye have two chaps, an upper chap and a nether chap.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha:

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha:

sp.speaker: wea.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha:

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: You said you would laugh but a little, but you laugh a great deal, why do ye laugh so much?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Because your wit was so great in expounding your meaning

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Yea , you may see it is a good thing to have wit.

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: wea.
sp.l: And what say you to wealth?

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: wealth? Marie wealth is better.

sp.speaker: wea.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And how say ye to will ?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Indeed, good will is a great matter,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Yea between a maid and a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Why? you are not in love boy?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: yes but I am, and in charity too.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Charity? alas poor child, thou in charity, ha, ha, now must I laugh.

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: But you laugh a great while, and you laugh very loud,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Then I owe you nothing for laughing, and you hear me the better

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: But now laugh not we.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No, you may be maddle, coddle: well here is three passing fine lads, if a man were able to keep them all: let me see wealth, O that is a sweet lad: then wit, O that is a fine lad: Will, O that is a pretty lad. Will, wit, and wealth, God lend ye health. I would I could guile their masters of two of them. If I had Fraud here that served Lady Lucre, he would teach me: he would teach me to tice one of them from his master: which of them now, if a man should steal one? Will? Nay, I care not for Will outsep he be good Will: Wit, a pretty child, but a man cannot live by wit: wealth, yea marie sir, I would I could win that wealth, for then I need neither will , nor wit, nor I need sell no Ballads but live like a mouse in a mill and have another to grind my meal for me, I will have a fling at one of them anon.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: Do you not forget yourself gaffer.

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: Have you not wares to sell gaffer?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: When do you show gaffer?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well remembered pretty lads, ye may see, children can teach old folks, I am an unthrift indeed: well , my wares shall out now. But sirs, how sell ye your wares, how many of these for a groat?

sp.speaker: wea.
sp.l: Our wares are not to be sold.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Not for silver nor gold? why hang they then in the open market?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: To be seen, not bought.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Then they are like ripe plums upon a rich man's tree that set men's teeth a watering when they be not to be bought: but what call ye these things?

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: Scutcheons.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Cushions, alas it were pity to sit on such fine cushions: but come my boys if you will buy any of my wares, here is my stall, and I will open and show strait.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: What dainty fine Ballad have you now to be sold?

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.p: Marie child, I have chipping Norton a mile from Chapel on the heath, A lamentable ballad of burning the Popes dog: The sweet Ballad of the Lincoln-shire bagpipes, And Peggy and Willy, But now he is dead and gone: Mine own sweet Willy is laid in his grave la, la, la, lan ti dan derry, dan da dan, lan ti dan, dan tan derry, dan-do .

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: It is a doleful discourse, and sung as dolefully.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Why, you cannot mend it, can ye?

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: What will you lay on that? For I myself dare lay six groats to six of your bald Ballads, that you yourself shall say I sing better than you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What a brag boy is this to comparison with a man, but boy boy, I will not lay six Ballads to six groats, but I will lay six Ballads to six jerks at your buttocks, that you shall not sing so well as I.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: That I shall not? No, possible you will not let me sing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I not let you? Is that spoken like wit? It is spoken like a Woodcock, how can I stay thee if thou wilt sing out thy throat?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Well then, to our bargain, six Ballads to six stripes, and who shall keep stakes?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Neither of your companions, for that is ask my fellow if I be a thief.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Will you keep the stakes yourself ?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Best of all, for I mean plainly and will pay if I loose, here is my six Ballads, they be ready: now how shall I come by your six stripes boy?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Down with your breeches, I will fetch a rod and deliver them straight.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Nay then I care not if thou keep stakes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You speak too late gaffer, having challenged pre-eminence.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Then let us lay no wager but sing for good fellowship.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Agreed, who shall begin?

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: O boy, who is the elder? Hast thou not heard give Flounders to thy elder?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You mistake the fish, trust me I am sure it is give place, but begin with good grace.

body.stage: Here simplicity. sings first, and Wit after, dialoguewise, both to music if ye will.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Now sirs, which singes best?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Tush, your copesmates shall not judge: friend, what say you, which of us sings best?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: To say truth, there is but bad choice,
How will you sell the ballad you sang, for I will not buy the voice.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Why wilt thou not buy my voice?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Because it will cost me more money to buy salad oil to keep it from rusting, than it is worth: but I pray ye honest man, what is this?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Read and thou shalt see.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I cannot read.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Not read and brought up in London, wentest thou never to school

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Yes, but I would not learn.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Thou wast the more fool: if thou cannot read I will tell thee, this is Tarltons picture: didst thou never know Tarlton?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: No: what was that Tarlton? I never knew him.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: What was he: a prentice in his youth of this honourable city, God be with him: when he was young he was leaning to the trade that my wife useth now, and I have used, vide lice shirt, water-bearing: Iwis he hath tossed a Tankard in Cornehil ere now, if thou knewest him not I will not call thee ingram, but if thou knewest not him, thou knewest nobody : I warrant here is two crack-ropes knew him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I dwelt with him.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Didst thou? now give me thy hand, I love thee the better.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And I too sometime.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: you child, did you dwell with him sometime?
wit dwelt with him indeed, as appeared by his rhyme,
sp.p: And served him well, and will was with him now and then , but soft, thy name is wealth, I think in earnest he was little acquainted with thee
sp.l: O it was a fine fellow as ever was born,
there will never come his like while the earth can corn:
O passing fine Tarlton I would thou hadst lived yet.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: He might have some, but thou showest small wit,
there is no such fineness in the picture that I see.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: And thou art no Cinque Port man, thou art not wit free,
the fineness was within, for without he was plain,
But it was the merriest fellow and had such jests in store,
that if thou hadst seen him, thou wouldst have laughed thy heart sore.

sp.speaker: weal.
sp.l: Because of thy praise, what is the price of the picture.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.p: I will tell thee my lad, come hither, if thou wilt be ruled by me thou shalt pay nothing, I will give it thee, if thou wilt dwell with me , and I promise thee this counsel is for thy performing, hadst not thou better serve a free man of the City, and learn a trade to live another day, than to be a serving boy in thy youth and to have no occupation in thine age, I can make thee free if thou wilt be my prentice.

sp.speaker: wea.
sp.l: Why, wealth is free everywhere , what need I serve you?
My Lord is a freeman if that may do me good.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.p: I cry ye mercy Master. boy, then your master is free of the lords company and you serve him that ye may be a Lord when ye come out of your years.

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: Wealth is a proud boy, gaffer what say you to me ?

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Thy name is wit, wilt thou dwell with me?

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: If I like your name and science, perchance we will agree

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: Nay, my name and mine honesty is all one, it is well known
He is a very fool that cannot beguile me, for my name is simplicity.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Coads gaffer were not you a meal-man once and dwelt with Lady Conscience?

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Yes, for want of a better.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What, a better man?

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: No, for want of a better mistress, she was as very a fool as I
We dwelt so long together that we went both a-begging .

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Indeed they that use a good conscience cannot suddenly be rich,
But I will not dwell with ye, you are too simple a master for me.

sp.speaker: Wil,
sp.l: Nor I will not dwell with you for all this worlds treasure.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: No, why whom serve you Will?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I serve my Lord pleasure.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: And whom serve you wit?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I serve my Lord policy.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: And whom serve you wealth?

sp.speaker: wea.
sp.l: I serve my Lord pomp.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.p: You should be served all with my Lord Birchley if you were well served, these lads are so lordly that louts care not for them: for wealth serves Pomp, Wit serves policy, and Will serves pleasure. wealth, will you buy this picture for your Lord?

sp.speaker: wea.
sp.l: No, it is too base a Present for pomp.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And policy seldom regards such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Wil,
sp.l: Come on gaffer, come on, I must be your best chapman,
I will buy it for pleasure, hold, there is a groat:

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Gramercy good Will, my wife shall love thee still,
And since I can neither get Wit nor wealth,
Let my wife have her will , and let me have my health.
sp.p: God forgive me, I think I never name her, but it conjures her, look where she comes, be mannerly boys that she knock ye not with her staff: keep your own counsel, and I will make ye laugh.
sp.l: What do ye lack, what lack ye.
Stand away these boys from my wares,
Get ye from my stall, or I will wring you by the ears.
Let my customers see the wares: what lack ye what would ye have bought.

body.stage: Enter painful Penury, attired like a water-bearing woman with her Tankard.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.l: You have customers enough and if they were ought,
What do ye with these boys here to filch away your ware?
You show all your wit, you will never have more care.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Content ye good wife, we do not filch, but buy.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.l: I meant not you, young master, Gods blessing on your heart
You have bought indeed sir I see, for your part.
Be these two young Gentlemen of your company,
Buy Gentlemen, buy ballads to make your friends merry.

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: To stand long with your burden, methinks you should be weary

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.l: True Gentlemen, but you may see poor painful penury
Is fain to carry three Tankards for a penny.
But husband I say, come not home to dinner, it is Ember day,
You must eat nothing till night, but fast and pray.
I shall loose my draught at Conduit, and therefore I will away.
Young Gentlemen God be with ye.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Wife, must I not dine today ?

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.l: No sir by my faith.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: If I must not eat, I mean to drink the more.
What I spare in bread, in ale I will set on the score.
How say ye my lads? And do I not speak wisely?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: methinks ye do , and it is pretty, that simplicity
Hath gotten to his wife plain painful Penury.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Yea, I thank God though she be poor and scarce cleanly,
yet she is homely, careful and comely.
Wit, wealth and Will, come to your Lords quickly.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Must the Scutcheons hang still?
yea, let them alone.

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: Farewell Master simplicity.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Farewell good Master. boys even heartily, even heartily, heartily.
And hear ye will , I thank you for your handsel truly.
Pretty lads, hark ye sirs how? Will, wit, wealth.

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: What is the matter you call us back so suddenly.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: I forgot to ask you whither your three Lords of London be courtiers or Citterners?

sp.speaker: wit.
sp.l: Citizens born and courtiers brought up : Is this all? Farewell.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.p: Citizens born and Courtiers brought up , I think so, for they that be born in London are half Courtiers before they see the Court, for finesse and mannerliness O passing, my manners and misbehaviour is mended half in half since I gave over being a meal-man and came to dwell in London: ye may see Time doth much, Time wears out iron horseshoes: Time tears out millstones: Time seasons a pudding well, and Time hath made me a free man, as free to bear water and sell Ballads, as the best of our copulation: I would have thought once my horse should have been free as soon as myself , and sooner too, for he would have stumbled with a sack of meal and lien along in the channel with it when he had done, and that some calls freedom, but it is but a dirty freedom, but ye may see, bad horses were but jades in those days: But soft, here comes customers: What lack ye, what it is ye lack, what lack ye? Come along and buy nothing: fine Ballads, new Ballads, what lack ye?

body.stage: Enter Nemo and the three Lords.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: My Lords come on, what suits have you to me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Renowned Nemo, the most only one
That draws no breath but of the eternal air,
That knowest our suit before we bound to speak
For thou art the very Oracle of thoughts:
Whose virtues do encompass thee about,
As the air surrounds this massy globe of earth.
Who hast in power whatever pleaseth thee,
And canst bestow much more than we may crave,
To thee we seek, to thee on knees we sue,
That thou wilt deign from thralldom to release,
Those lovely Dames, that London Ladies are.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: What, those three caitiffs long ago condemned?
Love, Lucre, Conscience, well deserving death,
Being corrupt with all contagion:
The spotted Ladies of that stately town.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Love, Lucre, Conscience we of thee desire,
Which in thyself hast all perfection,
Accomplished with all integrity:
And needst no help to do what pleaseth thee,
Who holdest Fame and Fortune both thy slaves,
And dost compel the Destinies draw the coach:
To thee we sue, sith power thou hast thereto,
To set those Ladies at their liberty.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: At liberty, thou spotless Magistrate,
That of the cause dost carry all regard,
Careless of bribes, of birth and parentage,
Because thyself art only born to bliss,
Bless us so much that Lords of London are,
That those three Ladies born and bred with us
May by our suites, release of thralldom find.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Release my Lords? why seek ye their release?
That have perpetual prison for their doom.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But Nemo can from thence redeem them all.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Their deeds were cause, not Nemo of their thrall.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Yet Nemo was the Judge that sentence gave.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: But Nemo never spilled, whom he could save:

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Thou from perpetual prison mayst revoke.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Death hath no power against him to strike a struck

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Thou only mild and courteous sir, vouchsafe
To grant our suit, and set those Ladies free.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: What is your purpose in this earnest suit?

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: To marie them, and make them honest wives.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: But may it be that men of your regard,
Lords of such fortune, and so famous place,
Will link yourselves with Ladies so forlorn,
And so disdained with more than common crimes?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Marriage doth make amends for many amiss.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And love doth cover heaps of combrous evils.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: And doth forget the faults that were before.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Mean as you say, ye need to say no more.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: In token that we mean what we have said,
Lo here our shields the prizes of our love:
To challenge all except thyself that dare
Deny those Ladies to be ours by right.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Woo them and win them, win them and wear them too,
I shall both comfort and discourage you my Lords,
The comfort is this, of all those former crimes
Wherewith the world was wont those dames to charge
I have them cleared and made them all as free
As they were born: no blemish left to see.
But the discourage (gentle Lords) is this,
The time of their endurance hath been long,
Whereby their clothes of cost and curious stuff
Are worn to rags, and give them much disgrace.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Alas good Ladies, was there none that sued
For their release, before we took it in hand?

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Yes, divers for fair Lucre sought release,
And some for Love would fain have paid the fees,
But silly Conscience sat without regard,
In Sorrows dungeon, sighing by herself :
Which when I saw that some did sue for Love,
And most for Lucre, none for Conscience:
A vow I made, which now I shall perform,
Till some should sue to have release for all,
Judged as they were, they should remain in thrall:
But you that crave their freedoms all at once
Shall have your suit, and see them here ere long,
A little while you must have patience,
And leave this place: go in my Lords before.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Becommeth us to wait on Nemo still,

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Not so: but Lordings, one condition more
You promise me, sith they are in my power,
I shall dispose them when they are released
Upon you three, as I shall think it best.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Do but command and we shall all subscribe.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Then go your ways, for I have here to do.
Sorrow draw near, tomorrow bring thou forth
Love, Lucre, Conscience, whom thou hast in thrall,
Upon these stones to sit, and take the air,
But set no watch or spy all what they do .

body.stage: Enter Fraud, Usury, Dissimulation, Simony and Simplicity.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: How happy may we call this merry day my mates, Wherein we meet, that once were desperate, I think, ever to have seen one another, when Nemo that upright Judge had by imprisoning our Mistresses, banished us (by setting such diligent watch for us ) out of London, and almost out of the world. But live we yet? And are we met? and near our old seat? Usury is it thou? Let me see, or hath some other stolen thy face? Speakest thou man?

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: No Fraud, though many have counterfeited both thee and me,
We are ourselves yet, and no changelings I see:
And why shouldest thou ask me man if I live:
The silly Ass cannot feed on harder forage than usury,
She upon thistles, and I upon a browne crust of a month old.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: So that Usury and an ass are two of the profitablest beasts that a man can keep, yet the one hath sharper teeth than the other .

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: But what means Dissimulation? He droops methinks . What cheer man? Why cousin, frolic a fit, art thou not glad of this meeting? What is the cause of thy melancholy?

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: Not melancholic, but musing how it comes to pass that we are thus fortunate to meet as we do .

sp.speaker: simo.
sp.l: I will tell thee why we met, because we are no mountains.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: But ye are as ill, for ye are monsters.

sp.speaker: simo.
sp.l: And men may meet though mountains cannot.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: In token that this meeting is joyful to us all,
Let us embrace altogether with hearts joy and affection.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: I see many of these old proverbs prove true, it is merry when knaves meet:

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: How sir, what is that?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: If a man had a casting net, he might catch all you.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Art not thou Simplicity?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: Goodman Simplicity. For I am married, and it like your mastership,
And you are mast. Fraud too, a pox on your worship.
I see, a fox and a false knave have all one luck, the better for banning,
And many of you crafty knaves live merrilier than we honest men.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Sirrah, bridle your tongue if you will be welcome to our company
No girds nor old grudges, but congratulate this meeting,
And sirs, if you say it, let us tell how we have lived since our parting.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: O it is great pity.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: What? to tell how we have lived:

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: No, that ye do live.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: Yet again sirrah. Usury, as for thee it were folly to ask, for thou livest but too well , but Dissimulation and simony, how have you two lived? discourse I pray you heartily.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Faith even like two mice in an aumbry that eat up all the meat, and when they have done, gnaw holes in the cupboard.

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.p: Fraud, after my scaping away at the Sessions where I shifted as thou knowest in three sundry shapes, one of a Friar, and they can dissemble: another like a woman, and they do little else: the third as a Saint and a Devil, and so is a woman. I was banished out of London by Nemo, to the country went I, amongst my old friends and never better loved than among the russet coats: once in a month I stole in of the market day to Leaden-hall and about, and sometime to Westminster hall. Now hearing some speech, that the Ladies should be sued for, for I am come in hope of my old entertainment, supposing myself not known of many, and hoping the three Lords will prevail in their suit, and I to serve one of them.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: He shall do well that gives thee a coat, but he should do better, that could take off thy skin.

sp.speaker: simo.
sp.p: And I have been a travailer abroad in other realms, for here I am so cried out against by preachers (and yet some ministers that be none, could be content to use me) that I was glad to be gone now in some other lands, and not very far off , I am secretly fostered, saving in Scotland, and the low Countries, they are reformed, they cannot abide me. Well now and then hither I came stealing over sea, and hearing as you here intend as you do ,

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: And for mine own part, amongst artificers and amongst a few bad conscienced Lawyers, I have found such entertainment, as doth pass, yet would I with Lucre fain be as I was.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: Fraud is as ill as a cutpurse, by the mass.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: And for Usury, the longer I live, the greater love I find
Yet would I be with Lucre, again to please my mind.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Here is a good fellow too, one of our acquaintance, how hast thou lived Simplicity?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: More honestly than all the rest of thy company: for when I might beg no longer, as begging was but bad, for you cozened me once of an alms, I fell to tankard bearing, and so got a wife of the same science, painful penury, then got I my freedom, and feeling my shoulder grow weary of the tankard, set up an easier trade to sell ballads.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Hadst thou a stock to set up withal?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Wise enough to tell you, I, and yonder is my stall, but beware I loose nothing, for if I do, I will lay it straight to some of you, for I saw none so like thieves I promise you, since I set up .

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: Ye are a wise man when your nose is in the cup, but soft who comes here? step we close aside, for these be the three Ladies for my life brought out of prison by their keeper, let us be whist and we shall hear and see all, Sirrah you must say nothing.

body.stage: Enter Sorrow and the three Ladies, he sets them on three stones on the stage.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: not till ye speak for I am afraid of him that is with ye women.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: O Sorrow when? when sorrow wilt thou cease
To blow the spark that burns my troubled soul?
To feed the worm that stings my fainting breast,
And sharp the steel that gores my dying heart?
My thoughts are thorns, my tears hot drops of lead,
I plain, I pine, I die, yet never dead.
If world would end, my woe should but begin,
Lo, this the case of Conscience for her sin:
And sin the food wherewith my worm was fed,
That stings me now to death, yet never dead.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Yet never dead, and yet Love doth not live,
Love that to loss in life her folly lent,
Folly the food whereon her frailty fed,
Frailty the milk that Natures breast did give,
Life, loss and folly, frailty, food and kind,
Worm, sting, thorns, fire and torment to the mind,
Life but a breath, and folly but a flower,
Frailty clay, dust the food, that fancy scorns,
Love a sweet bait to cover losses sower.
Flesh breeds the fire that kindles lustful thorns,
Lust, fire, bait, scorn, dust, flower, and feeble breath
Die, quench, deceive, fly, fade, and yield to death,
To death? O good, if death might finish all,
We die each day, and yet for death we call.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: For death we call, yet death is still in sight,
Lucre doth sealed in drops of melting gold,
Accusing Rust, calls on eternal might,
Where flames consume, and yet we freeze with cold:
Sorrow adds Sulphur unto Furies heat,
And chops them ice, whose chattering teeth do beat,
But sulphur, snow, flame, frost nor hideous crying
Can cause them die, that ever are in dying.
Nor make the pain diminish or increase,
sorrow is slack, and yet will never cease.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: When Sorrow ceaseth, Shame shall then begin,
With those that wallow senseless in their sin:
But Ladies I have drawn you from my Den,
To open air to mitigate some moan.
Conscience, sit down upon that sweating stone,
And let that Flint (love) serve thee for a seat,
And Lady Lucre, on that stone rest you.
And Ladies thus I leave you here alone,
Mourn ye, but moan not, I shall absent be,
Yet good it were sometime to think on me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Comfort it is to think on Sorrow past.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Sorrow remains when joy is but a blast.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A blast of wind is worlds felicity,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A blasting wind and full of misery.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: O Conscience, thou hast most tormented me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Me hath thy worm O Conscience, stung too deep.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: But more myself my thoughts tormented have
Than both of you in sorrows sullen cave.
From whence drawn forth I find but little rest,
A seat uneasy, wet, and scalding hot,
On this hard stone hath sorrow me assigned,

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: and on my seat myself I frozen find.
No flint more hard, no ice more cold than this.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: I think my seat some mineral stone to be.
I cold from it, it draws heat from me.
Ladies consent, and we our seats will view.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Dare we for shame our stained faces show.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: My double face is single grown again .

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: My spots are gone, my skin is smooth and plain.

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: Doff we our veils and greet this gladsome light.
The chaser of gloom sorrows heavy might.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Hail cheerful air and clearest crystal sky.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Hail shining sun and fairest firmament,
Comfort to those that time in woe have spent.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Upon my weeping stone is set remorse in brazen letters.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: And on this Flint in lead is Charity.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: In golden letters on my stone is Care.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then Lucre sits upon the stone of care.

sp.speaker: Lucre,
sp.l: And Conscience on the Marble of remorse,

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Love on the flint of frozen Charity,
Ladies alas, what tattered souls are we?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sorrow our hearts, and time our clothes hath torn

sp.speaker: Lucre,
sp.l: Then sit we down like silly souls forlorn,
And hide our faces that we be not known,
For Sorrows plagues tormented me no more,
Than will their sight that knew me heretofore.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: then will their sight that knew us heretofore
Draw ruth and help from them for our relief:

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: For our relief? for Conscience and for Love,
No help, small ruth that our distress may move:

sp.speaker: Loue,
sp.l: O Conscience thou wouldst lead me to despair,
But that I see the way to hope is fair,
And Hope to heaven directs a ready way,
And heaven to help is pressed, to them that pray.

sp.speaker: Lucre,
sp.l: That pray with faith, and with unfeigned remorse
For true belief and tears make prayer of force:

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then veil ourselves , and silent let us stay,
till heavens shall please to send some friends this way:

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Ladies unmasked, blush not for base attire,
Here are none but friends and servants all, deer Lady Lucre,
Dearer unto us than daily breath we draw from sweetest air;
Dearer than life, dearer than heaven itself ,
Deign to discover those alluring lamps,
Those lovely eyes more clear than Venus Star,
Whose bright aspects worlds wonder do produce,
Unveil I say that beauty more divine,
than Nature (save in thee) did ever paint:
that we sworn slaves unto our mistress, may
Once more behold those stately lovely looks,
And do those duties which us well beseems,
Such duties as we all desire to do .

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I know that tongue Lucre, beware of Fraud.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Of Fraud? Indeed by speech it should be he. Fra. what seekest thou

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Lucre, to honour thee with wit, with worth, with life, with all I
have , to be thy servant as I was before,
to get thee clothes, and what thou wantest else.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: No Fraud, farewell, I must be won no more,
to keep such servants as I kept before.

sp.speaker: simo.
sp.l: Sweet Lady Lucre, me thou mayst accept.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: How art thou called?

sp.speaker: simo.
sp.l: Simon.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: I? No, sir, Conscience saith.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: No Lucre, now beware, false not thy faith,
For Simoni is subject to perpetual curse.

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: As you two have sped, I would desire to speed no worse,

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Make you a suit, you may chance to speed better:

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: Not I, for of all , my tongue is best known,
But if I speak, it shall be to her that was once mine own:
Good Lady Love, thou little knowest the grief
that I thy friend sustain for thy distress,
And less believest what care I have of thee:
Look up good Love, and to supply thy wants,
Ask what thou wilt, and thou shalt have of me,
Of me that joy more in thy liberty,
Than in this life our light that comforts me.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: O gall in honey, serpent in the grass,
O befouled fountain of two bitter streams,
Dissimulation fed with Vipers flesh,
Whose words are oil, whose deeds the darts of death:
Thy tongue I know, that tongue that me beguiled,
Thyself a Devil, madest me a Monster vild.
From thee well known, well may I bless myself ,
Dear bought repentance bids me shun thy snare.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: O happy Love, if now thou can beware.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Marie, but hear ye motley-beard, I think this blindfold buzzardly hedge-wench spoke to ye, she knows ye though she see ye not, hark ye, you women, if you will go to the alehouse, I will bestow two pots on ye, and we will get a pair of Cards and some company, and win twenty pots more, for you play the best at a game called smelling of the four knaves that ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: Four? soft, yet they have not smelt thee.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: No, I am one more than is in the deck, but you will be smelled as soon as ye begin to speak, I will see what they will say to me: hear ye you women, wives, widows, maids, men's daughters, What shall I call ye? these four fellows (hark ye, shall I call ye crafty knaves) make me believe that you are the three that were the three fair Ladies of London.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Gentle Simplicity we are unhappy they.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now ye bad fellows, which of ye had such a word as gentle sim.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.p: Bad fellows ye Rascal? If ever you bring me pawn I will pinch ye for that word.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: I cry you mercy Master. Injury, Master. usury I meant not you,

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: If you mean us , we may be even with ye too.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Tut, I knew you an Ostler, and a thief besides , you have rubbed my horse heels ere now for all your pride: but Ladies, if ye be the three ladies, which of ye dwelt in Kent street? one of ye did, but I know not which is she, ye look all so like broom-wenches, I was once her servant, I will never be ashamed of her though I be rich, and I she be poor, yet if she that hath been my dame, or he that hath been my master come in place, I will speak to them sure, I will do my duty, which is Lady Consc?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Even I am she Simplicity.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I am glad ye are out of prison, I thought ye had forgot me,
sp.p: I went a-begging from you till the beadles snapped me up , now I am free and keep a stall of Ballads, I may buy and sell, I would you had as good a gown now as I carried once of yours to pawn to Usury here.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Gramercy good Simplicity. wilt thou be with me now?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: No I thank you heartily, I will beg no more, I cannot be with ye though I would for I am married to painful penury: Look now my proud stately masters, I may if I will , and you would if ye might.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: No, not dwell with such a beggar as Conscience.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: No, Fraud never loved Conscience since he was an Ostler.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: Who cares for Conscience but dies a beggar?

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: That will not Usury do, he will first take 3. score pound in the hundred.

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: love, look on me and I will give thee clothes.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: I will no more by thee be so disguised.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: Ye do the wiser, for his face looks like a cloak-back:

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: In thy affections I had once a place:

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: These fond affections wrought me foul disgrace,

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: I will make amends, if ought amiss were done:

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Who once are burned, the fire will ever shun.

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: And yet once burned too warm again may prove:

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Not at thy fire, I will be perfect love?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: I promise you the wenches have learned to answer wittily,
Here is many fair proffers to Lucre, and love,
But who clothes poor Conscience, she may sit long enough .

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: I will cloth her straight:

body.stage: Usury takes Frauds cloak, and casts it on Consc

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: Will you master Usury, that is honestly spoke.
Ha, that is no gramercy to cloth her with another man's cloak,
But I see you have a craft in the doing Master. Usury,
Usury covers Conscience with Frauds cloak very cunningly.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Alas who loads my shoulders with this heavy weed,
Fie, how it stinks, this is perfumed indeed,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Marie gup goody Conscience, indeed I do you wrong,
But I will quickly right it, my cloak shall not cumber you long.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: All this while Lucre knows not I am here,
But now will I to her, mark how I speed.
Lady, the fairest that Nature ever formed,
Lodestone of Love, that draws affections darts.
The only object to all human eyes,
And sole desired Dainty of the world,
thy Vassal here, a virtue in thy need
Whom thou by license of the law mayst use,
tenders himself , and all his services
to do thy will in duty as to-fore,
Glad of thy freedom as his proper life.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: Lady Lucre, you love an apple, take heed the Caterpillar consume not your fruit.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Why who is it that maketh this latest suit?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: It is usury.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Great is the service he hath done for me,
But Usury now I may not deal with thee.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: the Law allows me Madam, in some sort.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: But God and I would have thy bounds cut short,

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: For you I reck not, but if God me hate,
Why doth the Law allow me in some rate?

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: Usury slanders both Law and state,
the Law allows not though it tolerate,
And thou art sure be shut out at heaven gate.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: You were ever nice, no matter what you prate:

sp.speaker: Simp,
sp.p: Then it will be with him as it is at a great man's house in dinner time: he that knocks when the door is shut comes too late,

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Well Usury, Fraud, and Simony
Dissimulation hearken unto me,
My tongue (although in memory it be green)
Cannot declare what horrors I have seen,
Ne can it enter into mortal ears
Unmortified: the furies, fires and fears,
the shrikes, the groans, the tortures and the pains,
that any soul for each of you sustains.
No pen can write, how Conscience hath me scourged,
When with your faults my soul she ever urged:
Arithmetic doth fail to number all,
the plagues of sorrow in the Den of thrall:
then tempt me not, nor trouble me no more,
I must not use you as I did before,
If you be found within fair London's gate,
You must to prison, whence we came of late.
Conscience will accuse ye if ye be in sight.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: That scurvy Conscience works us all the spite:

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: Well Lucre, yet in thee we have delight.

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: Yonder come some, we must take our flight.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Birds of a feather will fly together, but when they be taken then are they baken, yonder comes a customer, I will to my stall:
sp.l: Love, Lucre, and Conscience, blind man buff to you all.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Conscience, Love, Lucre, Ladies all what cheer?
How do ye like the seats you sit upon .

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: O pure unspotted Nemo sole paragon,
Of Love, of Conscience and perfection,
The Marble of Remorse I sit upon
Sweats scalding drops, like bitter brinish tears.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: So should remorse when Conscience feels her gilt
But gentle Love how feelest thou thy flint?

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: O sharp and cold, I freeze unto my seat,
The Flint holds fire, and yet I feel no heat,
But am benumbed and frozen every joint.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: O Love, so cold is charity in these times:
Lucre, how sit you?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Upon a heavy stone, not half so cold, not half so hot as theirs,
But of some secret power, for I do find and sensibly I feel,
That I from it exhale an earthly cold,
And it from me doth draw a kindly heat.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Such force hath Care of Lucre in itself ,
To cool the heart and draw the vital spirits,
And such the true condition of you three:
Remorse of Conscience, Charity of Love,
And Care of Lucre, such your uses be:
But Ladies now your sorrow lay aside,
Frolic fair Dames, an unexpected good
Is imminent through me unto you all:
Three Lords there be your native countrymen,
In London bred, as you yourselves have been .
Which covet you for honourable wives,
And presently will come to visit you,
Be not abashed at your base attire,
I shall provide yon friends to deck you all.
If I command, stand up , else sit you still .
Lo, where they come: my Lords the Dames be here.

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: Why are they wimpled? shall they not unmask them?

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: It is for your sake, for Policy they do it:

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Much may their fortune and their feature be,
But what it is we cannot thus discern.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: You shall in time Lord Pomp, be yet content.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Their fame is more than cause or reason would,
May one of these be pleasures paragon?

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Pleasure, be pleased and use no prejudice.
Madams stand up , mislike not their attire,
That shall be mended as yourselves desire.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Their port, and their proportion well contents:

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Right stately dames, if they were well attired:

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: May we not see their beauty what it is?

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Yes Lordings yes, Lucre, lift up thy veil.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Of beauty excellent.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Of rare perfection.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: A dainty face.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Unmask Love.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sweet love indeed.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: A lovely face.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: A gallant grace.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Conscience, uncover.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Beauty divine.

sp.speaker: Pom
sp.l: A face angelical.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Sweet creature of the world.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Enough for once, Ladies sit down again :
As cunning chapmen do by curious wares,

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Which seldom shown do most inflame the mind,
So must I deal, being dainty of these Dames,
Who seldom seen shall best allure these Lords:
A while my Lords, I leave you with these three,
Converse, confer on good conditions,
I will right soon return with such good friends
As it concerns to cloth these dainty ones
If any in my absence visit them,
Know their intent, and use your skill therein.

sp.speaker: pol
sp.l: Ladies, to call to mind your former lives
Were to recount your sorrows on a row,
Omitting then what you have been or be ,
What you may be I will speak, so it please you,
Wives to us three, Ladies to London Lords,
pomp, Pleasure policy, men of such regard,
As shall you guard from evil, once matched with us ,
And Policy presents this good to you.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: With London's Pomp may one of you be joined,
Possessing more than Fortune can afford,
Fortune is a fool, but heavenly providence
Guards London's pomp, and her that shall be his:

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: And London's pleasure, peerless in delights,
Will deign to make one of these Dames his own,
Who may with him in more contentment live,
Than ever did the Queen of Ethiope.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Though silence Lords, our modesty enforce,
Nemo can tell the secrets of our thoughts,
Nemo that women's minds can constant keep,
He shall for us you answer good my Lords,
I speak for all , though ill beseeming me.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You speak but well : My Lords step we aside
To note these fellows, what they do intend.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Nemo can tell, for he doth follow them.

sp.speaker: Falsh.
sp.l: Ladies to you, to some of you, we come,
Sent from such friends as much affect your good,
With garments, and with complements of cost
Accordant well to dames of such degree: I come to Lucre.

sp.speaker: D. Dea.
sp.l: I to love am sent with no less cost than could be got for coin
Which with my message I deliver would,
Could I discern which of these Dames were she ,

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Friend, I am Love, what bringest thou there to me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Beware good Love, from whom and what thou takest.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: No whispering friend, but show it openly,
The matter good, you need not be ashamed:
From whom comest thou?

sp.speaker: D. Dea.
sp.l: That I conceal from any but from love,

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: From whom come you sir?

sp.speaker: Falsh.
sp.l: That shall lucre know, and none but she.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Then speak aloud, for whispering here is barred.

sp.speaker: Falsh.
sp.l: Then neither will I do nor speak at all .

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Then I will speak and tell what you are both,
Thyself art Falsehood, and art sent from Fraud,
To compass Lucre with a cloak of craft,
With lawn of lies, and call of golden guile.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Pack you my friend, for if you stay a while
You shall return no more to him that sent you.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Thou from Dissimulation art sent,
And bringest a gown of glossing, lived with lust,
A Farthingale of vain boast, and fan of flattery,
A Ruff of riot, and a cap of pride,
And double dealing is thy name and office both.

sp.speaker: D. Dea.
sp.l: Falsehood, let us go, we are deciphered.

sp.speaker: Falsh.
sp.l: Lucre, thou loosest here a princely gift.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: lucre consumes being won by Fraud or shift,
Thus Lords you see how these are qualified,
And how these Ladies shun that sharp rebuke,
Which some deserve by taking of such toys,
As women weak are tempted soon with gifts,
But here they come that must these Ladies deck.
lucre, arise, come from the stone of Care.

body.stage: Enter honest Industry, pure Zeal, and Sincerity.

sp.speaker: ho. Indust.
sp.l: Fair lucre, lo what honest Industry
To thee hath brought, to deck thy dainty self,
Lucre by honest Industry achieved
Shall prosper, flourish, and continue long,
Come to thy chamber to attire thee there.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Thou mayst depart with honest Industry.

sp.speaker: P. Zeal.
sp.l: And Love arise from Charities cold Flint,
Pure Zeal hath purchased robes to cover Love,
Whilst love is single, Zeal shall her attire
With kind affection, mortifying lust,
Come love with me these garments to put on:

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: love, follow zeal and take his ornaments.

sp.speaker: Sincer.
sp.l: Rise Conscience from that Marble of Remorse,
That weeping stone that scalds thy parched skin,
sincerity such robes for thee hath brought,
As best beseems good Conscience to adorn:
Come follow, that thou mayst go put them on,
For Conscience clothed by sincerity,
Is armed well against the enemy.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Follow him Consc. fear not, thou art right.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Most reverend Nemo thanks for this good sight,
lucre is clothed by honest Industry.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: love by pure zeal.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: And Conscience by sincerity.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Lordings, thus have you seen them at the first,
And thus you see them, trust me, at the worst,
Depart we now, come hence a day or two,
And see them decked as dainty Ladies should,
And make such choice as may content you all .

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thanks righteous Nemo we the London Lords
Only to thee ourselves acknowledge bound.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.p: Come on gentle husband, let us lay our heads together, our purses together, and our reckonings together, to see whether we win or loose, thrive or not, go forward or backward, do you keep a book or a score?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A score wife? you mean for the Alehouse, do you not? I would have her examine me thereof no further, for I am in too far there, more than I would she should know.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.p: I mean no alehouse score, but a note of your wares, let me see, First you began to set up with a Royal, how much money have ye? what ware, and what gain?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I have five shillings in money, two shillings in wares, or thereabout, and I owe two shillings and eight pence upon the score, how much is that? five shillings, two shillings, and two shillings and eight pence.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.p: That is nine shillings and eight pence, so we are worse by a a groat then when we began, well once again I will set ye up , here is four groats I have got by bearing water this week, make up your stock, and run no Who more behind. Who comes here?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: What lack ye? What do ye lack?

p.foreign: Me lacka da moonee pour de feene verie feene Franche knack da feene gold buttoone, de braue bugla lace, a da feene gold ringa, you be free man, mee vn'Forriner, you buy a me ware, you gaine teene pownd by lay out teene shellenga.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Wife. what hard luck have we that cannot make x. shillings now to gain x. pound: why, x. pound would set us up for ever .

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.p: Husband see the ware, and if ten shilling will buy it, it shall go hard but we will make that money: Friend, show my husband your wares

p.foreign: Looke you dere mastra de feene buttoonede la gold, de ringa de gold, de bugla sheane, two shelleng vne doozen de buttoone, vne shellenga vne Ring, tis worth x, shelleng, but mastra and matressa mee mussa make money to go over in my own countrey, but mee loose teene pownd pour hast to go next tyde or to morrow.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.l: Here is five shillings buy them of this stranger.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Friend you have not stolen them, but you make them, well, I will buy them in the open market, and then I care not, here is ten shillings, deliver me the wares.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: Dear master, o poor necessity maka me sell pour grand, grand loss, you shall gain x. pound at least, gor boy.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: Merchant, I think I am even with ye now for calling me Ostler, you will thrive well with such bargains, if ye buy, ye know not what, Fraud hath fitted ye with worse than your ballads.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.l: You will warrant them gold sirrah,

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: wee, so good gull as you pay for: Adieu Monsieur.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Adieu Monsieur: Adieu fool, sell such gold buttons and rings for so little money, good Lord what pennyworths these strangers can afford: now wife let me see, x. pound, when we have ten pound, we will have a large shop, and sell all manner of wares, and buy more of these, and get ten pound more, and then ten pound, and ten pound, and twenty pound, then thou shalt have a taffeta hat and a guarded gown, and I a gown and a new cap, and a silk doublet, and a fair house.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.p: I thank ye husband, well , till then look well to your wares, and I will ply my water-bearing and save and get, and get and save till we be rich, but bring these wares home every night with ye:

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Tush, I shall sell them before night for ten pound, go wife, go , I may tell you I am glad this French fellow came with these wares, we had fallen to examining the Ale-score else, and then we had fallen out, and the alewife and my wife had scolded: well , a man may see, he that is ordained to be rich, shall be rich: go woman.

body.stage: Enter Nemo and the three Lords, as though they had been chiding.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: From whence good Lords grew this hot argument?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thou knowest already, yet if thou wilt hear,
For this we strive: fond pleasure makes account
Summing his bills without an auditory,
That Lady Lucre ought of right be his.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: So I affirm, and so I will maintain
That pleasure ought by right Dame Lucre have ,
To bear the charge of sports and of delights.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Nay to support the haughty magnificence
And lordly Pomp of London's excellence,
Befits it rather Lucre join with me,
By whom her honour shall be most advanced.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: More fit for pomp than pleasure, but most fit
That Policy with Lucre should be matched,
As guerdon of my studies and my cares
And high employments in the common wealth:

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: What pleasure can be fostered without cost:

sp.speaker: pom,
sp.l: What Pomp or port without respect of gain?

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: What policy without preferment lives?

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Pleasure must have Lucre:

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: pomp hath need of Lucre:

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: policy merits lucre:

sp.speaker: ple,
sp.l: Pleasure dies without Lucre,

sp.speaker: pom,
sp.l: Pomp decays without Lucre,

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: policy droops without lucre:

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Thus Lords you show your imperfections:
Subject to passions, straining honours bounds,
Be well advised, you promised to be ruled,
And have those Dames, by me disposed to you,
But since I see that human humours oft
Makes men forgetful of their greater good.
Be here a while, Dame lucre shall be brought
By me, to choose which Lord she liketh best,
So you allow her choice with patience.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Go, we abide thy doom till thy return,

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: If lucre be not mad she will be mine,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: If she regard her good she will be mine.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: If she love happy life, she will be mine,
Women love Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Women love Pomp.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Women use Policy: and here she comes that must decide the doubt.

body.stage: Enter Nemo with Conscience all in white.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Conscience content thee with a quaint conceit,
Conceal thy name to work a special good,
Thou art not known to any of these Lords,
By face or feature, till they hear thy name,
Which must be lucre for a fine device,
And Conscience clear indeed is the greatest gain,
Lo, Lordings here fair lucre whom ye love:
lucre, the choice is left unto thyself ,
Which of these three thou wilt for husband choose.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The modesty that doth our sex beseem
Forbids my tongue therein to tell my thought,
But may it please my Lords to pardon me,
Which of you three shall deign to make such choice,
Him shall I answer to his own content,

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: If lucre please to match with Policy,
She shall be mistress over many men.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: If lucre like to match with London's Pomp,
In stately port all others she shall pass.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: If pleasure may for wife fair lucre gain,
Her life shall be an earthly Paradise.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Lo, Lucre, men, and port, and pleasant life
Are here propounded, Which wilt thou accept?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Lord policy, Love were the only choice
Methinks for you, that all your cares employ
And studies for the love of common wealth,
For you Lord pleasure, Conscience were a wife,
To measure your delights by reasons rule,
In recreation Conscience help to use.

sp.speaker: plea
sp.l: Were Conscience half so sweet as is thyself ,
Her would I seek with suites and services.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: No less accomplished in perfection
Is Conscience, than this Lady I protest,

sp.speaker: plea,
sp.l: But on this Dame hath pleasure fixed his heart,
And this or death the period of his love.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Lucre with pomp most aptly might combine

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Lucre, or Love if case thou wilt be mine,
Let pass thy name, thyself do I desire,
Thee will I have except thyself deny,
With thee to live, or else for thee to die.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: What if I deny?

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Then will I have her.

sp.speaker: pol
sp.l: If we deny?

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: So much the rather.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: The rather in despite of us ? Not so.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: My Lords, no quarrel, let this Lady go ,
And if ye trust me, I will content ye both,
pleasure, this is not lucre:

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: She is Lucre unto me: but be she Love or Conscience, this is she.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Whom you will , have ?

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Spite of the Devil, I will .

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: Must it not be my Lord if I agree?

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Agree.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Some further proof it fits of you to see:

sp.speaker: ple,
sp.l: Receive a pawn, my heart, my hand, and oath,
To be thy own in love, in faith, and troth.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Thus you are fast, and yet myself am free:

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: I know in ruth thou wilt me not refuse:

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I know not that, but other I will not choose.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: It is enough , Lord pleasure, do not fear,
Conscience will use you as becomes her best.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: And art thou Conscience? welcomer to me than either love or Lucre,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: God send grace I be,

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: My Lords be pleased, ere long shall you be sped,
As much to your contents as pleasure is,
Say but the word, myself shall soon present
Lucre and love, well worthy such as you.

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: Right thankfully those favours we will receive,

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: My Lords, if your affairs in present be not great
Greater than any, save regard of life,
Yea even the greatest of the common wealth,
Prepare ye to withstand a stratagem,
Such as this Land nor London ever knew.
The Spanish forces Lordings are prepared,
In bravery and boast, beyond all bounds
To invade , to win, to conquer all this land.
They chiefly aim at London's stately pomp,
At London's pleasure, wealth and policy.
Intending to despoil her of them all,
And over all those lovely Ladies three.
Love, lucre, Conscience, peerless of the rarest price.
to tyrannize and carry hardest hand.
From Spain they come with Engine and intent
to slay, subdue, to triumph and torment:
myself (so heaven would) spoil of them had,
And Diligence, dear Lords, they call my name.
If you vouchsafe to credit my report,
You do me right, and to yourselves no wrong,
Provided, that you arm you, being warned,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Diligence, thy service shall be known,
and well rewarded: Nemo, for a time
Conceal this Dame, and live secure unseen,
Let us alone whom most it doth concern,
to meet and match our overweening foes.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Nemo keep close, and Conscience pray for us .
Be gone and recommend us to our God.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My Lords, if ever , show your honours now,
Those proud usurping Spanish tyrants come,
To reave from you what you do most regard,
to take away your credit and your fame.
to race and spoil our right renowned town:
And if you love or lucre do regard,
Or have of Conscience any kind of care,
The world shall witness by this action,
And of the love that you to us pretend,
In this, your valour shall assurance give:
More would I speak, but danger is in delay,
You know my mind, and heavens record my thoughts,
When I with prayers for you will penetrate,
And will in heart be present in your fight:
Now pleasure, show what you will do for me.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: I will be turned to pain for thy sweet sake.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Fair Conscience fear not, but assure thyself
What kind affection we so ever bear
to Love and Lucre, in this action
Chiefly for thee our service shall be done.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: For Conscience sake more than for Lucre now,

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: For Love and Conscience, not despising Lucre.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Only for Conscience will I hazard all.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: And I from hence will her convey a space,
Till you return with happy victory.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Farewell my Lords, for me my Lords, for me.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Diligence, what number may there be?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: A mighty host, and chiefly led by three,
Who brave it out in show, as men assured
Of victory, sans venture, or repulse.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How near be they?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: So near my Lords, that each delay is death,
Stand on your guard, they come as challengers,
to bruise your shields, and bear away your prize,
Mounting the seas, and measuring the land
With strong imaginations of success,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well , Diligence go get in readiness
Men and munition, bid our pages ply
To see that all our furniture be well ,
Wit, Wealth and will to further wars be fit,
My Lords, I would I might advise ye now,
To carry as it were a careless regard,
Of these Castilians, and their accustomed bravado:
Lord Pomp, let nothing that is magnifical,
Or that may tend to London's graceful state
Be unperformed. As shows and solemn feasts,
Watches in armour, triumphs, Cresset-lightes,
Bonfires, bells, and peels of ordinance.
And pleasure, see that plays be published,
May games and masks, with mirth and minstrelsy,
Pageants and school-feasts, bears, and puppet plays,
Myself will muster upon Mile-end green,
As though we saw, and feared not to be seen:
Which will their spies in such a wonder set,
To see us reck so little such a foe,
Whom all the world admires, save only we:
And we respect our sport more than his spite,
That Iohn the Spaniard will in rage run mad,
To see us bend like Oaks with his vain breath.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: In this device such liking I conceive,
As London shall not lack what pomp can do ,
And well I know that worthy Citizens
Do carry minds so frank and bountiful,
As for their honour they will spare no cost:
Especially, to let their enemy know.
Honour in England, not in Spain doth grow.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: And for the time that they in pleasure spend,
It is limited to such an honest end,
Namely, for recreation of the mind,
With no great cost, yet liberal in that kind,
That pleasure vows with all delights he can
To do them good, till death to be their man.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Of policy they trial have at large:

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Then let us go and each man to his charge.

body.stage: Enter Simplicity led in by Usury.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: I sir? Why alas I bought them of a stranger, an old French man for good gold, and to be worth ten pound, for so he told me, I have good witness, for my own wife was by, and lent me part of the money.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: And what did they cost you?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: Ten shillings every penny.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.p: That argues you are guilty: Why? could ye buy so many rings and buttons of gold think ye for ten shillings? Of whom did ye buy them?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: Of an old French man, the old French disease take him.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: And where dwells that old French man?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: In France I think, for he told me he was to go over the next tide, or the next day, my wife can tell as well as I, if ye think I lie, for she was by.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.p: A good answer, he dwells in France and you dwell here, and for uttering copper for gold you are like to loose both your ears upon the pillory, and besides loose your freedom.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Nay, if I loose my ears, I care not for my freedom, keep you my freedom, so I may keep my ears, is there no remedy for this Master. Usury?

sp.speaker: vsurie.
sp.l: None, except you can find out that old French man.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: Peradventure I can, if you will let me go into France to seek him:

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: So we may loose you, and never see him, nay that may not be.

sp.speaker: Simp,
sp.l: You have a good pawn there, good master Usury be good unto me.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.p: Nay, now I will pinch ye, you villain, ye know how ye have ever used me, but now off goes your ears at least,

sp.speaker: Sim.
