sp.l: Nay, good master Usury take all my goods and let me go,

body.stage: Enter Fraud, Dissimulation, Simony in canvas coats like Sailors.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: What is the matter Usury, that this poor knave cries so:

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: O Master Fraud, speak to him to let me go :

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: Fraud? Ye villain, call me not by my name, and ye shall see I will speak to him to let ye go free: Usury, of all old fellowship let this poor knave pack, if the matter be not too heinous.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p: No fie, his fault is odious, look here what stuff he would utter for gold, flat copper, and he saith, he bought them of an old frenchman

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: But thou didst not sell them, didst thou?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: No sir, I would have but laid them to pawn for five pounds to him.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: That was more than they be worth, I promise thee a foul matter, well , thou must loose thy ware and be glad to escape, so Usury, at my request ye shall let the poor man go .

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.p: Well , for this once I will, sirrah, get ye packing, and take heed of such a piece of work again while ye live.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: There is divers pieces of work in that box, pray ye give me some of my goods again , a ring or something.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: Not an inch, and be glad ye scape as ye do ,

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: Alas, I am undone, there is all the wealth and stock I have .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do ye long to loose your ears, be gone ye foolish knave.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I thank ye Master Fraud: I will not go so far, but I will be near to hear and see what the meaning of these fellows in this canvas should be, for I know Fraud, Dissimulation, and simony to be those three: here I think I am unseen.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: Usury, thank me for this good booty, for it is I that holp ye to it, for I sold them to him for gold indeed in the shape of an old French artificer, come give me half for I deserve it, for my part was the first beginning of this Comedy, I was ever afraid, lest the fool should have known me, for ye see now though disguised, he call me by my name.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Did he so? I am glad I have found the french man, now I will raise the street, but I will have my wares again, and prove ye as ye were, ever both false knaves I believe.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Kill him, stab him, out villain, he will betray us all.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.p: What a fool were you to speak before he was gone, now you have lost your part of this too, for he will go complain, you will be sought for, and I made to restore these things again .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Not if thou be wise, thou wilt not tarry the reckoning, for seest thou not us three? Dissimulation simony and my self ?

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: Yes: What means these canvas suites? Will ye be Sailors?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Usury make one, this is our intent: let us see that none hear us now: the Spaniards are coming thou hearest with great power, here is no living for us in London, men are grown so full of conscience and religion, that Fraud, Dissimulation and Simony are deciphered, and being deciphered are also despised: and therefore we will slip to the sea, and meet and join with the enemy, and if they conquer as they may, for they are a great army by report, our credit may rise again with them, if they fail and retire, we may either go with them and live in Spain, where we and such good fellows are tolerated and used, or come slyly again hither, so long as none knows but friends.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: But will you do thus you two?

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: And thou too I hope, why, what should we do?

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: Whatsoever ye do , be not traitors to your native country.

sp.speaker: simo.
sp.p: It is not our native country, thou knowest, I Simony am a Roman, Dissimulation a Mongrel, half an Italian, half a Dutchman Fraud so too, half French, and half Scottish: and thy parents were both Jews, though thou wert born in London, and here Usury thou art cried out against by the preachers: join with us man to better thy state, for in Spain preaching toucheth us not.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.p: To better my state, nay, to alter my state, for here where I am, I know the government, here can I live for all their threatening, if strangers prevail, I know not their laws nor their usage, they may be oppressors, and take all I have , and it is like they are so, for they seek that is not their own. Therefore here will I stay sure, to keep what I have , rather than be a traitor upon hap and had I wist: and stay you if ye be wise, and pray as I pray, that the preachers and all other good men may die, and then we shall flourish, but never trust to strangers courtesy.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: We shall trust but to our friends and kin, you will not go with us , yet for old acquaintance keep counsel, betray us not, for we will be gone to sea, I am afraid yen foolish knave have belayed the streets for us .

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: Let me go afore ye, if any such thing be, I will give ye inkling.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Do, farewell Usury: and as he goes one way, we will go another, follow sirs, never trust a shrinker, if he be your own brother.

body.stage: Enter the three Lords with their Pages and Fealty a Herald before them, his coat having the arms of London before, and an Olive tree behind.

sp.speaker: pol:
sp.l: Fealty, thou faithful Herald of our town,
Thou true truce-keeper, and sure friend in peace,
Take down our shields, and give them to our boys:
Now Fealty, prepare thy wits for war,

sp.speaker: pol:
sp.l: To parley with the proud Castillians
Approaching fast the frontiers of our coast:
Wit, here, my Page in every message shall
Attend on thee, to note them and their deeds:
I need not tell thee, they are poor and proud,
Vaunters, vainglorious, tyrants, truce-breakers,
Envious, ireful, and ambitious,
For thou hast found their facing and their brags,
Their backs, their coffers, and their wealth, their rags,
But let me tell thee what we crave of thee,
To scan with judgment what their leaders be,
To note their presence and observe their grace,
And truly to advertise what they seem,
Whether to be experienced in arms,
Or men of name those three that lead the rest,
the rest refer we to thy own conceit,

sp.speaker: Feal,
sp.l: I hope in this my duty to discharge, as heretofore

body.stage: Simplicity, make a great noise within, and enter with three or four weaponed.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Clubs, clubs, nay come neighbours come, for here they be , here I left them, arrant thieves, rogues, cozeners, I charge ye as you will answer, prehend them, for they have undone me, and robbed me, and made me the poorest free man that ever kept a ballad stall:

sp.speaker: A Constable,
sp.l: I charge ye keep the peace and lay down your weapons:

sp.speaker: pomp,
sp.l: Who raised this tumult? Speak, what means this stir?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: O I am undone, robbed, spoiled of all my stock, let me see, where be they? Keep every street and door, examine all that comes for Fraud that cozener.

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: Masters, what mean you in these troublous times to keep this coil?

sp.speaker: Const,
sp.l: Alas my Lord, here is a poor man robbed, or cozened.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: I am robbed O my boys, my pretty boys, I am undone, saw ye no thieves, nor no crafty knaves, what be all these?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Simplicity, away, these be our Lords, offend them not for fear.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: I seek not them, I seek for Fraud that robbed me.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Go seek elsewhere , for here is no place for such.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My friends depart, and qualify this stir,
And see peace kept within the walls I charge ye.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I will my Lord, come Simplicity. we came too late to find your losses.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: Pray for me my boys, I think I shall hang myself I come ever too late to speed.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now Lords, let Honours fire inflame our thoughts,
And let us arm our courage with our cause,
And so dispose ourselves to welcome them,
Do me the favour (if I may entreat)
To be the first to front the foe in face,
The Vanguard let be Policies this once,
Pomps the maine battle, pleasures the Rearward:
And so bestow us if you think it good.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I think it good, and time that it were done.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: I think it good, and wish the enemy come.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: And here they come, as brave as Philips son,
And his Ephestion, wont to be arrayed
In glittering gold, and party coloured plumes,
With curious pendents on their Lances fixed,
Their shields impresed with gilt copertiments,
Their Pages careless, playing at their backs,
As if with conquest they triumphing came.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: If they be conquered greater is their shame,
But Diligence go post alongst the coast,
To tell the news, and look to welcome them,
Let us alone: My Lords you hear the news,
More words were vain, I know ye well resolved.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And here they come, O proud Castillians.

body.stage: Enter first Shealty the Herald: then Pride, bearing his shield himself, his imprese, a Peacock: the word, Non parilli His Page Shame after him with a Lance, having appendant gilt, with this word in it, Sur le Ciel , Ambition, his imprese, a black Horse salient, with one hinder foot upon the Globe of the earth, one fore foot stretching towards the clouds, his word, Non sufficit orbis : His page Treachery after him, his pendent Argent and Azure, an armed Arm catching at the Sun beams, the word in it, Et gloriam Phoebi . Last, Tyranny, His imprese, a naked Child on a spears point bleeding, his word, Pour sangue , His page, Terror, his pendent Gulls, in it, a Tigers head out of a cloud, licking a bloody heart: The word in it, Cura Cruor . March once about the stage, then stand and view the Lords of London, who shall march towards them, and they give back , then the Lords of London wheel about to their standing, and the other come again into their places, then Policy sends Fealty: their Heralds coat must have the arms of Spain before, and a burning ship behind.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My Lords, what mean these gallants to perform,
Come these Castilian Cowards but to brave?
Do all these mountains move to breed a mouse?
Fealty, go fetch their answer resolute
How they dare be so bold, and what they dare do here.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.l: What wouldst thou Herald?

body.stage: As Fealty. is going towards them, they send forth Sheal.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: Parley with those three, Herald.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.l: They scorn to grace so mean a man as thou
with parley or with presence.

sp.speaker: Fea:
sp.l: Do they scorn? what, are thy masters, Monarchs every one?
Or be they Gods? or rather be they Devils?
Scorn they a Heralds presence and his speech?
Name them, that I may know their mightiness,
And so avoid of duties some neglect.

sp.speaker: shea.
sp.l: Monarchs in minds, and Gods in high conceits,
That scorn you English, as the scum of men,
Whom I ne dare without their license name,
Fore whom thy duties all are few and base,

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: Imperious Spaniard, do a Herald right.
Thyself art one, their Trowch man if thou be,
Be thou my Trunk, that I my message may
through thee convey to them from London Lords.

sp.speaker: shea.
sp.l: Base English groom, from beggars sent belike,
Who for their mate thee malapert account,
Dare I (thinkst thou) these Lords magnificent,
Without their special pleasure understood,
Once move with message, or with show of speech?

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: More servile thou to loose a Heralds due,
That is in field a kings companion,
But if thou dare not my Embassage do ,
Stand by and stop not my access to them.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.l: Rather will I return and know their minds.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now boy, what news.

body.stage: When Sheal. goes to them, Wit goes to the 3. Lords of London.

sp.speaker: Wit,
sp.l: The fearful Herald of yen famous crew
Durst not your message to his masters tell,
Till Fealty with contumelious words,
(Yet was the Spaniard brave and hot in terms)
Enforced him for their answer resolute.

body.stage: The Span. whisper with their Her.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Which now belike our Herald shall receive,
For theirs comes to him.

sp.speaker: sheal.
sp.l: It pleaseth them to be magnifical,
And of their special graces to vouchsafe
A counterview of Pages, and of shields,
And countermessage by us Heralds done:
A favour which they seldom grant to foes,
Go thou for those, I meet thee will with these.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: My Lords yen braving Spaniards wish
A counterview of Pages and of shields,
But what they mean or be I know not yet:
Happily you may by their impreses view,
Or I by parley some conjecture give,
So please it you your pages and your shields
With me to send, their Herald comes with theirs.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Our shields I reck not, but to send our Wealth

sp.speaker: Feal.
sp.l: Accompanied with Wit and Will, no peril.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: It is my wealth, but keep him if they dare,
I will fetch him double if they do my Lords,

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Boys, take our shields and spears, for they come on.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Vail Spaniard, couch thy Lance and pendent both,
Knowest where thou art? Here will we bear no braves

body.stage: When the English boys meet the other, cause them to put down the tops of their Lances, but they bear up theirs.

sp.speaker: Wea.
sp.l: Down with your point, no loft born Lances here
By any stranger be he foe or friend.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Well dost thou note the couching of thy Lance,
Mine had ere this else gored your Spanish skin.

sp.speaker: Feal.
sp.l: Well done my boys, but now all reverence.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.l: Advance again your Lances now my boys.

sp.speaker: S. Pride.
sp.l: Dicito nobis ideo qui ades, quid sibi velint ist haec Emblemata? Dicito (inquam) lingua materna: nos enim omnes belle intelligimus, quamuis Anglice loqui dedignamur .

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: Then know Castillian Caualieros this,
The owners of these Emblems are three Lords
Those three that now are viewing of your shields,
Of London, our chief city are they Lords,
Policy, pomp, and pleasure be their names:
And they in honour of their mistresses,
Love, Lucre, Conscience, London Ladies three,
Emblazoned these Scutcheons, challenging
Whom durst compare, or challenge one of them,
And Policy a Tortoise hath Impressed,
Encompassed with her shell, her native walls,
And prouidens securus is his word:
His page is Wit, his Mistress Lady Love.
pomp in his shield a Lily hath portrayed,
As paragon of beauty, and boon grace:
Glorie sauns peere his word, and true it is,
With London's Pomp Castile cannot compare,
His Page is wealth, his mistress Lucre hight.
Pleasure, the dainty of that famous town,
A Falcon hath emblazoned, soaring hie,
To show the pitch that London's Pleasure flies:
His word Pour temps , yet never stoops to train,
But unto Conscience, chosen for his dear.
His Page is Will, and thus the effect you hear.

l.foreign: Buena buena per los Lutheranos Angleses.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Agedum , Go too then and declare thy Lords, their
shields, their pages, and their purpose.
Speak man, fear not, though Spain use messengers ill,
It is Englands guise to entreat them courteously.

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.l: Three Caualieros Castillianos here,
Without Compeers in compass of this world:
Are come to conquer, as full well they shall
this molehill Isle, that little England hight,
With London that proud paltry market town,
And take those Dames Love, Lucre, Conscience
Prisoners, to use or force as pleaseth them.
The first (now quake) is Spanish Majesty,
That for his imprese gives Queen Iunoes Bird,
Whose train is spanged with Argus hundred eyes,
the Queen of Gods scorns not to grace him so.
His word is Non par illi , none his like:
Yet is his page or henchman Modesty,
Lucre the Lady that shall be his prize:
And in his pendent on his Lances point,
Sur le Ciel his word, above the heavens.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Whilom indeed above the heavens he was,
Could he have kept him in that blessed state,
From thence for pride he fell to pit of pain,
And is he now become the pride of Spain?
And so his page not Modesty but Shame.
Well , on the rest.

sp.speaker: sheal.
sp.l: Don Honour is the next grand peer of spain,
Whose imprese is a Courser salient,
Of colour Sables, darkening air and earth,
Pressing the Globe with his disdainful foot.
And sallying to aspire to rolling skies,
Non sufficit orbis is his haughty word,
The world sufficeth not high Honours thoughts,
And on the pendent fixed on his Lance,
A hand is catching at the sunny beams:
and gloriam Phoebi, and the Suns bright coach,
Honour would guide, if he might have his will .
His Page is Action tempering still with state.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Himself Ambition, whom the heavens do hate,

sp.speaker: shea.
sp.l: And Love the Lady that he hopes to gain,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: His thoughts distract from foul distempered brain
Proves him the very firebrand of Spain:
And in his shield his black disordered beast,
Scaling the skies, scornful to tread the ground,
And both his words, proud words prove perfectly
Action his page to be but Treachery,
ever attendant on Ambition: but to the third.

sp.speaker: Sheal.
sp.l: The third grand Caualiero is Government,
Severe in Justice, and in judgment deep:
His imprese is a naked Infant gored
Upon a Lance, signifying, severity.
His word, pour sangue , for blood of enemies
He bends his forces: on his pendent is
A Tiger licking of a bleeding heart:
And Cura Cruor is the word thereon,
His care is for blood of those that dare resist:
Yet hight his Page that follows him, Regard,
and he for Conscience to this conquest comes.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The Government of spain is Tyranny,
as do his imprese and his words declare,
His Page is Terror: for a Tyrant fears
His death, in diet, in his bed, in sleep,
In conscience: Spite the Spanish tyranny
Hath shed a sea of most unguilty blood: well , what is the end?

sp.speaker: Shea.
sp.l: The end is best you yield, submitting you to mercy of these Lords.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Before we fight? soft sir, ye brave too fast.
Castilians, know that Englishmen will knock, but say,
Doth Spanish Pride for London's Lucre gape,

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: And would their Tyranny Conscience captive have ?

sp.speaker: pol:
sp.l: Doth their Ambition London's love affect?

sp.speaker: sheal.
sp.l: All this they will, and pray upon your town,
And give your lands away before your face:
alas, what is England to the power of spain?
a Molehill, to be placed where it pleaseth them.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: But in this Molehill many Pismyres be,
All which will sting before they be removed,
What is thy name?

sp.speaker: sheal.
sp.l: Shealty,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: An Irish word, signifying liberty, rather remissness,
looseness if ye will , why hath thy coat a burning ship behind?

sp.speaker: shea.
sp.l: to signify the burning of your fleet by us Castillians.

sp.speaker: pol:
sp.l: It rather means your commonwealth is on fire,
about your ears, and you were best look home,
a commonwealth is compared to a ship,
If yours do flame, your country is hot, beware.

sp.speaker: Feal.
sp.l: I see Castilians, that you marvel much
at this same Emblem of the Olive tree
Upon my back : Lo this it signifies.
Spain is in wars, but London lives in peace,
Your native fruit doth wither on your soil,
and prospers where it never planted was.
This London's Fealty doth avouch for truth,
Herald of war, and Porter of their peace,
Command ye me no service to my Lords.

l.foreign: Quid tibi cum domini mox seruient miseri nobis: discede,

sp.speaker: Feal.
sp.l: Quid mihi cum dominis seruietis miseri meis ?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: shealty, say unto yen Thrasos three.
The Lords of London dare them to the field,
Pitying their pride and their Ambition,
Scorning their Tyranny, and yet fearing this,
That they are come from home and dare not fight,
But if they dare in joint or several arms,
Battle or combat, him that Lucre seeks,
Your Spanish pride, him dare I from the rest.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: That bloody cur, your Spanish Tyranny,
That London's Conscience would force with cruelty,
I challenge him for Conscience sake to fight,
a Lord of London, and I pleasure hight.
And shealty, when Citizens dare them thus,
Judge what our Nobles and our courtiers dare:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Say if thou wilt that London's policy
Discerns that proud Ambition of spain,
And for he comes inflamed with London's love,
In combat let him conquer me and have her,
this is Loves favour, I her servant am.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: This Lucre's favour, Pomp for her will fight.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: this Conscience favour, she my mistress is.

sp.speaker: shea.
sp.l: You craven English on your dunghills crow.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: You Spanish Pheasants crow upon your perch,
But when we fire your coats about your ears,
And take your ships before your walled towns,
We make a dunghill of your rotten bones,
And cram our chickens with your grains of gold:

sp.speaker: shea.
sp.l: You will not yield?

sp.speaker: ple,
sp.l: Yes, the last month.

sp.speaker: shea.
sp.l: Farewell.

body.stage: Retire Heralds with the pages to their places.

sp.speaker: S. Pride.
sp.l: Vade.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Herald, how now?

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: Yen proud Castillians look for your service.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: So do we for theirs: but Fealty, canst thou declare to me the cause why all their pages follow them, when ours in shows do ever go before.

sp.speaker: Fea.
sp.l: In war they follow, and the Spaniard is warring in mind

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But that is not now the cause, yen three are Pride, Ambition Tyranny.
shame follows pride, as we a proverb have ,
pride goes before, and shame comes after,
Treachery ever attends upon Ambition:
And Terror always with a fearful watch,
Doth wait upon ill conscienced Tyranny:
But why stay we to give them space to breath:
Come, Courage, let us charge them all at once.

body.stage: Let the three Lords pass towards the Spaniards, and the Spaniards make show of coming forward and suddenly depart.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: What braving cowards these Castillians be,
My Lords let us hang our Scutcheons up again ,
And shroud ourselves but not far off unseen,
To prove if that may draw them to some deed,
Be it but to batter our impresed shields.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Agreed, here Fealty, hang them up a space.

body.stage: They hang up their shields, and step out of sight. The Spaniards come and flourish their rapiers near them, but touch them not, and they hang up theirs, which the Lords of London perceiving, take their own and batter theirs: The Spaniards making a little show to rescue, do suddenly slip away and come no more.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Facing, faint-hearted, proud and insolent,
That bear no edge within their painted sheaths,
That durst not strike our silly patient shields.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Up have they set their own, see if we dare
Batter on them, and beat their braving Lords.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Let them not yonder hang unhacked, my Lords.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: With good advise, that we be not surprised, and good enough.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Myself will onset give on Prides, at your Peacock sir.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: At Tyrannies will I bestow my blow, wishing the master.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I at Ambitions strike, have at his pampered Jade.

sp.speaker: S. Pride.

l.foreign: Fuoro Viliagos, fuoro Lutheranos Angleses, fuoro

sp.l: sa, sa, sa.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Their shields are ours, they fled away with shame,
But Lordings, whilst the stratagem is fresh,
And memory of their misfortune green,
Their hearts yet fainting with the novel grief,
Let us pursue them flying, if you say it,
Happily, we may prevent their passage yet.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: With speed and heed the matter must be done,

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Therefore you Policy shall our leader be.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: The day is ours, fair Ladies let us joy,
The joyful day that all men may rejoice,
Yet only I am thankful for this good.
And your good day at hand approacheth fast.
Wherein you shall be joined to three such Lords,
As all the cities under heavens bright cope,
Cannot with all their glory match in worth,
Lucre, Lord Pomp a victor comes to thee:
Love, look thou for Lord policy as well :
And Conscience for her well reformed Fear,
pleasure, that only made his choice of her.
Upon that day triumphant shall we feast,
Wherein (Madams) your honours nill be least.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Against their coming might my read be hard,
Prepare would we garlands of Laurel green,
To welcome them, more for the common good,
Than for affection private that we bear.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: To meet them coming will not be amiss,
But what know we how they will take such work,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Report may be much more than there is cause,
We may them meet and greet with joyful hearts,
And make them garlands when we know their minds.

body.stage: Enter the three Lords with the Spanish Shields and Diligence

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: And here they come with new impresed shields,
My Lords well met, and welcome from your foes.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Lord pomp, well met, and welcome home again .

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.l: Lord policy, well met, and welcome home again .

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Lord pleasure, welcome with unfeigned heart.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Fair joy and Lady xx. thousand thanks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Fair Love, and Lady, twice as many thanks.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Fair and beloved Lucre, though I speak last,
As kindly I thy welcome do accept,
As heart can think, pen write, or tongue can tell.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Now speak my Lords, how have ye sped?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Right well : thanks unto him that gave the day to us ,
The pride of Spain was cloaked with Majesty,
And Shame his page, (nicknamed) Modesty,
Spanish Ambition, Honour would be called,
And Treachery his page, termed Action.
Their Tyranny was clipped Government,
Terror his page, was (falsely) named Regard,
But God above hath given them their reward.
They with dishonour left their shields behind,
The only prises purchased by us now,
And those (fair Ladies) we present to you,
Love, this is thine, and he that gives it thee.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: In lieu whereof your gift and her I give
Again to you, that merit more than both.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The greatest gift and good could me befall.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Fair lucre, lo, my present and my self.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.l: Which I with Nemos license gladly take.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Take her Lord pomp, I give her unto thee,
Wishing your good may ten times doubled be.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: the wished good this world could give to me.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Of duty I (my dear) must give thee this,
that art my comfort and my earthly bliss.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: Now Lords, I hope you are contented all,
pomp with his Lucre, policy with Love:
pleasure with Conscience, joy fall you from above :
And thus to you my promise is performed,
And I expect that yours as well be kept,
That present preparation may be made
to honour those with holy marriage rites,
that I in presence of the world may give
these as my daughters unto you my sons.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: By my consent one day shall serve us all,
Which shall be kept for ever festival.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And on that day in honour of these Dames,
these shields in triumph shall be born about.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: With pageants, plays, and what delights may be
to entertain the time and company.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: So it please you Lordings, methinks it were meet,
that the Ladies took care to provide their own toys.
Myself need to help them, who know their minds well,
For I can keep women both quiet and constant.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: It pleaseth us well that you will take the pains.
Fair ones, for a while we betake you to your business.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Ladies, adieu.

body.stage: the Lords bring them to the door, and they go out and Ne.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Beloved, farewell.

body.stage: Fra. gives Pol. a paper, which he reads and then says

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: It seems by this writing sir, you would serve me,
Is your name Skill? whom did you serve last?

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: An ill master, my Lord, I served none but myself .

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Have ye never served any heretofore?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Yes, divers my Lord, both beyond sea and here with your patience, my good Lord, not offending the same, I think I am your poor kinsman, your Lordship, policy, and I Skill, if it like ye.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You say very well, and it is very like, I will answer ye anon.

body.stage: Diss. gives Plea. a paper which he reads, and says.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Is your name fair semblance that wish to serve me.

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.p: Please it your Lordship, fair semblance, I am well seen, though I say it, in sundry languages, meet for your Lordship, or any noble service, to teach divers tongues, and other rare things.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: I like ye very well, stay a while for your answer,

body.stage: Enter Usury and gives a paper to Pomp which he reads, and saith,

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Master Usury, I thank ye that ye offer me your service, it seems to be for your old mistress sake, Lady lucre, stay but a while, I will answer you with reason.

body.stage: The three Lords go together, and whisper, and call Diligence, Diligence goes out for a marking iron, and returns.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: How now my hearts, think ye we shall speed.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Diligence, Come hither.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: I cannot tell what you shall , but I am sure I shall .

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: I am as like as any of ye both.

sp.speaker: Vsu, Fraud. Dis,
sp.l: Whist man, he is Skill.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: Skill, Why dost thou seek to serve Lady Love?
What profit will that be?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Tut hold thee content, I will serve but a while, and serve mine own turn and away.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Master Usury come hither, you desire to serve me, you have done Lady Lucre good service you say, but it was against God and Conscience you did it, neither ever in your life did ye anything for Love: Well to be short, serve me you shall not, and I would I could banish you from London for ever , or keep you close prisoner, but that is not in me, but what is or may be, that strait you shall see: By policies counsel this shall be done, Diligence bring that iron, help me my Lords.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Give me the iron Pomp, Cousin Skill help to hold him,

body.stage: Fraud lays hold on him but Diss. slip away.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sirrah, policy gives you this mark, do you see,
A little x. standing in the midst of a great .C,
Meaning thereby to let all men understand,
that you must not take above bare x. pound in the hundred at any hand,
And that too much too, and so be packing quietly:
And know that London's Pomp is not sustained by usury,
But by well ventured merchandise and honest industry.

sp.speaker: Vsu,
sp.l: I would I had never seen ye, if this be your courtesy.

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: Now Cousin Skill, alias, filthy Fraud,
No kinsman to Policy, nor friend to the state.
Instead of serving me, Diligence take him to Newgate,
Ask not why , sir, but Diligence if he do strive,
Raise the street he is unweaponed, and thou hast a weapon on:
And now Lords when ye will , about our affairs, let us be gone,

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Agreed, but what is become of fair semblance my man.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: A crafty villain, perceiving how we meant to Usury, slipped away.

body.stage: Enter Simplicity in haste, and give the Lords a paper to read.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: All hail, all rain, all frost, and all snow, be to you three Lords of London on a row:
Read my supplantation and my suit ye shall know,
Even for Gods sake above , and three Ladies sakes below.

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Master. Diligence, Do me favour, you know I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Step aside till my Lords be gone, I will do for you what I can.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: What is here my boy, what is here? pleasure, this suit is sure to you, for it is mad stuff, and I know not what it means.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.p: Neither do I: sirrah, your writing is so intricate, that you must speak your mind, otherwise, we shall not know your meaning.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You sue for three things here, and what be they tell them:

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Cannot you three tell, and the suit to you three? I am glad a simple fellow yet, can go beyond you three great Lords of London.

Why my suite, look ye , is such a suite, as you are bound in honour to hear, for it is for the puppet-like wealth, I would have no new orders, nor new sciences set up in the city, whereof I am a poor freeman, and please ye, as ye may read in my bill there , simplicity freeman. But my Lords, I would have three old trades, which are not for the common wealth, put down .

sp.speaker: Ple.
sp.l: And after all this circumstance, sir what be they?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: they be not three what lack ye , as what do ye lack, fine Lockerome, fine Canvas, or fine Holland cloth: or what lack ye, fine Ballads, fine Sonnets: or what lack ye, a purse or a glass, or a pair of fine knives: but they be three, have ye anies, which methinks are neither sciences nor occupations, and if they be trades, they are very malapert trades, and more than reason.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: As how sir? Name them.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: Will you banish them as readily as I can name them?
the first is, have ye any old iron, old male, or old harness?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And what fault find ye with this?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: What fault? I promise ye a great fault, what have you or any man else to do to ask me if I have any old iron? What if I have , or what if I have not? Why should you be so saucy to ask?

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.p: Why fool, it is for thy good to give thee money for that, that might lie and rust by thee.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: No my Lord, no. I may not call you fool: it is to mark the houses where such stuff is, that against rebels rise, there is harness and weapon ready for them in such and such houses, and what then? the rusty weapon doth wound past surgery, and kills the Queens good subjects: and the rest of the old trash will make them guns too, so it is good luck to find old iron, but it is nought to keep it, and the trade is crafty, and now my L. policy, I speak to you, it were well to put it down .

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Wisely said, which is your second? Is that as perilous?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Yea, and worse: It is, have ye any ends of gold and silver? this is a perilous trade, covetous, and a ticement to murther, for, mark ye, If they that ask this should be evil given, as Gods forbid, they see who hath this gold and silver, may not they come in the night break in at their houses, and cut their throats for it? I tell ye, gold and silver hath caused as much mischief to be done as that, down with it.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: they that have it need not show it.

sp.speaker: Sim,
sp.p: tush, they need ask no such question, many a man hath delight
to show what he hath, the trade is a ticing trade, down with it:

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: Now your third sir:

sp.speaker: sim,
sp.p: that is the craftiest of all, wherein I am disabused, for that goes under the colour of simplicity, have ye any wood to cleave?

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: A perilous thing, what hurt is there in this sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O do you not perceive the subtlety? why sir, the Woodmongers hires these poor men to go up and down with their beetles and wedges on their backs, crying, have ye any wood to cleave, and laugh to see them travel so laden with wood and iron: now sir, if the poor men go two or three days and be not set a-work (as sometimes they do ) the Woodmongers pay them and gain by it, for then know they there is no wood in the city, then raise they the price of billets so hie, that the poor can buy none. Now sir, if these fellows were barred from asking, whether there were wood to cleave or not, the woodmongers need not know but that there were wood, and so billets and faggots would be sold all at one rate, down with this trade, we shall sit a-cold else my Lords.

sp.speaker: Ple.
sp.l: I promise you a wise suit, and done with great discretion.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.p: Yea, is it not? might ye not do well to make me of your counsel I believe I could spy more faults in a week, than you could mend in a month:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well , for these three faults the time serves not now to redress:

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.l: No marie, for you three must be married suddenly, and your feast must be dressed:

sp.speaker: pom,
sp.p: Against which feast, repair you to Diligence, and he shall appoint you furniture and money, and a place in the show, till when farewell.

sp.speaker: sim.
sp.p: Farewell my Lords, farewell my three Lords, and remember that I have set each of ye a fault to mend: well , I will go seek Master. Diligence that he may give me forty pence against the feast sir reverence:

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: What is it Master. Fraud, ye would demand of me?

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.p: Sir this you know, though yourself be a man of good reckoning, yet are ye known an officer unto these three Lords, and what discredit it were to me, being a noted man to pass through the streets with you being officer, or if any of my friends should suspect me with you, and dog us , and see me committed to Newgate, I were utterly discredited, here is a purse sir, and in it two hundred Angels, look sir, you shall tell them.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Here are so indeed, what mean ye by this, I will not take these to let ye escape.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I mean not so sir, nor I will not give half of them to be suffered to scape, for I have done no offence, though it please them to imprison me, and it is but on commandment, I shall not stay long, but I will give you this purse and gold in pawn to be true prisoner, only give me leave to go some other way, and home to my lodging, for my boots and other necessaries, for there I will leave word I am ridden out of town, and with all the haste that possibly I may, I will meet you at Newgate, and give you an Angel for your courtesy; there is the purse.

body.stage: Fraud gives him a purse like the other.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: I hazard (as you know) my Lords displeasure herein, and yet to pleasure you I will venture this once, but I pray ye make haste that I be not shent, I would not for ten Angels it were known.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: If I tarry above an hour, take that gold for your tarrying.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: I do not fear that you will forfeit so much for so little cause.

body.stage: Enter Nemo with Desire, Delight, and Devotion, the three Lords of Lincoln.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: My Lords of Lincoln, have you such title and such interest
To Love, Lucre, and Conscience, as ye say?
Who gave you leave to have access to them?
I am their father by adoption,
I never knew of Love twixt them and you:
And to perpetual prison they were doomed,
From whence I only might deliver them.
Which at the suit of three most matchless Lords,
Their countrymen, in London bred as they,
I have performed, and freed them from their bonds,
And yet have bound them in their freedom too
To Policy, to pleasure, and to pomp,
Three Lords of London, whose they are in right,
Contracted wives, and done by my consent,
And even tomorrow is the marriage day,
Except your coming stay or break it off,
I will go call their Lords to answer you,
The (yonder covert Baron) meddle not.

sp.speaker: Desire,
sp.l: Fetch them Lord Nemo, we will here attend.

sp.speaker: Delight,
sp.l: Attend we may, but unto little end,
The Ladies are in hucksters handling now,

sp.speaker: Deuo,
sp.l: I would I had my time in praying spent,
That I in wooing Conscience did consume.

body.stage: Enter the three Lords of London and Nemo.

sp.speaker: Desire,
sp.l: Here come the Lords, let us show good countenance man.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Yet more ado before we can enjoy
The joys of marriage with our mistresses?
Be these the Lords that title do pretend?
My Lords of Lincoln, so we hear you be.
What are your names?

sp.speaker: Del,
sp.l: Devotion, Desire, and Delight.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Which comes for Lucre?

sp.speaker: Desire,
sp.l: I Desire.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Which for Conscience?

sp.speaker: Deuo,
sp.l: I Devotion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Which for Love?

sp.speaker: Del,
sp.l: I Delight.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You shall be answered straight.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: I can answer them quickly: ye cannot have them, nor ye shall not have them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Stay pleasure, soft: My Lord Desire, you Lucre seek, Desire of lucre (be it without reproach to you my Lord) is covetousness which cannot be separated long from that: read my Lord.

body.stage: Point to the stone of Care.

sp.speaker: Desire,
sp.l: In golden letters on this stone is written Care.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Care with desire of lucre well agrees, the rather for that London's Lucre may not be separated from London's Pomp, so you may take that stone if ye will, but the Lady you cannot have .

sp.speaker: Desire,
sp.l: And a stone is a cold comfort instead of Lucre.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Devotion to Conscience (I speak now to you my Lord that are learned) is sorrow for sin, or in one word read.

body.stage: point to the stone of Remorse.

sp.speaker: Deuot.
sp.l: On this sweating stone in brass is set Remorse.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And that is your portion, for Conscience is bestowed on London's Pleasure, because London makes a conscience what pleasure they use and admit, and what time they bestow therein, and to what end: so my Lord Devotion, either that or nothing.

sp.speaker: Deuo,
sp.l: A stone is a hard lot instead of a Lady.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My Lord Delight, that do delight in Love, you must I love, for making choice of mine. Love is my portion, and that Flint is yours.

sp.speaker: Del,
sp.l: Here in lead is written, Charity: and what of this?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: If you be (as I doubt not) honest delight in love, then in the best sense, you can have but Charity, if you be (which I suspect not) other Delight in Love, you must be noted for Concupiscence, and that you will blush to be: well Charity is your best, then that is your portion: For, mark ye, London's policy joins with London's Love: to show, that all our policy is for love of London's common wealth: and so our love cannot be separate from our policy, you bear this.

sp.speaker: Delight,
sp.l: A Flint is a hard change for so fair a wife.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And thus Lords, Desire of Lucre may take Care, Devotion of Conscience may have Remorse, and Delight of Love may have Charity, other recompense none.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: And so we three leave you three with Care, Remorse, and charity.

sp.speaker: Desire,
sp.l: With Care and Remorse I swear, ye do leave us , but what charity I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Deuot.
sp.p: Well , yet must we use Charity though we fail of our desire, and we are answered with such reason as is not to be gainsaid.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord your calling is to persuade to Charity, but if I use patience, it shall be perforce.

sp.speaker: Deuo,
sp.p: Yet being so wisely warned, methinks we should be armed And take this in worth, that the world wonder no further, I will take up my hard burden of Remorse and be gone.

sp.speaker: Desire,
sp.p: It is good to follow examples of good, I will take this heavy burden of Care, and follow as I may.

sp.speaker: Del,
sp.p: Because I will not be singular, I will frame myself to follow, taking this cold portion of Charity as my share.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Come on Master. Diligence, I have been seeking ye, as a man should seek a load of hay in a needles eye.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: And why hast thou sought me (I pray thee) so earnestly?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.p: Why? For this ointment, these shells, these pictures, do ye not know this Countus mountus cum this da mihi?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: What money, why? Do I owe thee any money?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Owe me? Tush, no man, what do ye talk of owing? Come, and yet I must have some certain sigillatum and deliberatum in praesentia . do you not understand sir? Forty pence and furniture by my Lord pomps pointment, against the wedding day: to be one of the show-makers, I do not say shoemakers, and yet they be honest men.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: I understand thee now, and thou shalt want neither money nor furniture for that: sawest thou not Fraud lately?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No, a Fox ferret him, for if I could find him, I would make him fast enough for cozening me of ten shillings for certain copper buttons and rings, I thought to have been a haberdasher, and he hath made me worse than a hay-maker.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: I may say to thee in counsel, but I will have no words of it, he hath overreached me too: but if thou spy him first, let me understand, and if I see him first thou shalt have knowledge, for I will tell thee, but laugh not, he showed me a purse with a hundred pound in Angels, which he would deliver me in pawn to be my true prisoner, because for his credit, he was loath to go with me through the streets to Newgate: I refused it at first, but at last by his entreaty I was content to take his pawn, and thinking he had given me the right purse of gold, he had another like it, which he gave me with counters, and so went away, I never did see him since, but mum, no words of it.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: No words quoth he, that is a stale jest, would you be cozened so?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Well , so it is now, come follow me for thy furniture and money.

body.stage: Enter Dissimulation and Fraud in caps, and as the rest must be for the show.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: The coast is clear, come follow Fraud and fear not, for who can decipher us in this disguise, thus may we shuffle into the show with the rest, and see and not be seen, doing as they do , that are attired like ourselves .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: That is, to stand amongst them, and take as they take, torches or anything to furnish the show, now if we we can pass but this day unseen, let tomorrow shift for itself as it may, I promise thee Dissimulation thou art very formal.

sp.speaker: Dis,
sp.l: Not more than thyself Fraud, I would thou sawest thy picture

sp.speaker: Frau,
sp.l: Picture here, picture there, let us follow our business.
Strew the fair flowers and herbs that be green,
To grace the gayest wedding that ever was seen.
If London list to look, the streets were never so clean,
Except it was when best it might, in welcome of our Queen:
Three lovely Lords of London shall three London Ladies wed,
Strew sweetest flowers upon the stones, perfume the bridal bed.
Strew the fair flowers. .

body.stage: Enter first Diligence with a Truncheon, then a boy with Policies Lance and shield, then Policy and Love hand in hand: then Fraud in a blew gown, red cap and red sleeves, with Ambitions Lance and shield, then a boy with Pomp's Lance and shield, then Pomp and Lucre hand in hand: then Dissimulation with Prides Lance and shield, then a boy with Pleasures Lance and shield: then Pleasure and Conscience hand in hand: then Simplicity with Tyrannies Lance and shield: they all going out, Nemo stays and speaks.

sp.speaker: Ne,
sp.l: These Lords and Ladies thus to church are gone,
An honoured action to solemnise there,
With greater joy will they return anon,
Than Caesar did in Rome his Laurel wear.
Lord policy hath Love unto his Fear,
Lord pomp hath Lucre to maintain his port,
Lord pleasure Conscience to direct his sport.
Usury is marked to be known,
Dissimulation like a shadow fleets,
And Simony is out of knowledge grown,
And Fraud unfound in London but by fits.
Simplicity with painful penury sits,
For Hospitality that was wont to feed him,
Was slain long since and now the poor do need him.
That Hospitality was an honest man,
But had few friends (alas) if he had any,
But Usury which cut his throat as then
Was succoured, and sued for by many.
Would Liberality had been by thy side,
Then Hospitality, thou hadst never died.
But what mean I, one of the marriage train,
To mourn for him will never be had again .
His Ghost may walk to mock the people rude:
Ghosts are but shadows, and do sense delude:
I talk too long, for lo this lovely crew
Are coming back , and have performed their due.

body.stage: Return as they went, saving that the blew gowns that bare shields, must now bear torches: Simplicity going about, spies Fraud, and falleth on his knees before Pleasure and Conscience, saying.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: O Lady Conscience that art married to Lord pleasure,
Help thy servant simplicity to recover his lost treasure:
A boon my Lords, all for Love and Lucre sake,
Even as you are true Lords, help a false lout to take,

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Thou shalt have help, speak, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: See you yen fellow with the torch in his hand?
One the falsest villain that is in this land,
Let him be laid hold on that he run not away,
And then ye shall hear what I have to say.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: Diligence bring him hither, good Lords and Ladies stay.

sp.speaker: simp.
sp.l: O Master Fraud, welcome to the buts,
Now I will have my ten shillings in spite of your guts,
The French Canker consume ye, you were an old Frenchman,
Da gull buttoone, gull renga, bugla lase, you cozened me than,
My Lords I beseech ye that at tyborne he may totter,
For instead of gold, the villain sold me copper.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Is this true Master. Skill?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: It is true in a sort my Lord, I thought to be pleasant with him being my old acquaintance, and disguised myself like an old French Artificer and having a few copper knacks, I sold them to him to make sport for ten shillings, which money I am content to pay him again so shall he have no loss though he have made a little sport.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.l: First give him an Angel before my face. Simplicity, art thou pleased?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly I am pleased to take a good Angel for ten shillings, speciously of such a debtor as Master. Fraud: but now I am to be pleased otherwise, that is, to see him punished, I promise ye the people love him well , for they would leave work and make half holiday to see him hanged.

sp.speaker: ple.
sp.p: That his punishment may please thee the better, thou shalt punish him thyself : he shall be bound fast to yen post, and thou shalt be blindfold, and with thy torch shalt run as it were at tilt, charging thy light against his lips, and so (if thou canst) burn out his tongue, that it never speak more guile.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O Singulariter Nominatiuo, wise Lord pleasure: Genetiuo bind him to that post, Datiuo , give me my torch, Accusat . For I say he is a cozener. Vocat . O give me room to run at him. Ablat . take and blind me. Pluraliter, per omnes casus. Laugh all you to see me in my choler adust to burn and to broil that false Fraud to dust.

body.stage: Bind Fraud, blind Simplicity, turn him thrice about, set his face towards the contrary post, at which he runs, and all to burns it, Dis. standing behind Fraud, unbinds him, and whilst all the rest behold Simplicity. they two slip away: Pleasure missing Fraud saith.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.p: Wisely performed, but soft sirs, where is Fraud? O noble villain, gone whilst we Who beheld the other: Who loosed him? Who let him slip? well , one day he will pay for all: unblind Simplicity.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How now, have I heated his lips? have I warmed his nose? and scorched his face? Let me see, how looks the villain? have I burned him?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: Thou hast done more, for thou hast quite consumed him into nothing, look, here is no sign of him, no not so much as his ashes.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Very few ashes if there be any, ye may see what a hot thing anger is, I think that the Torch did not waste him so much as my wrath: well , all London, nay, all England is beholding to me, for putting Fraud out of this world, I have consumed him and brought him to nothing and I will tread his ashes under my feet, that no more Frauds shall ever spring of them: But let me see, I shall have much anger, for the Tanners will miss him in their leather, the Tailors in cutting out of garments, the Shoemaker in closing, the Tapsters in filling pots, and the very oystermen to mingle their oysters at Billinsgate, yet it is no matter the world is well rid of such a crafty knave.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: Well now thou art satisfied, I wish all here as well contented,
And we my Lords that praise this happy day,
Fall we on knees and humbly let us pray,

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: First that from heaven upon our gracious Queen,
All manner blessings may be multiplied,
That as her reign most prosperous hath been ,
During worlds length so may it still abide,
And after that with saints be glorified.
Lord grant her here health, hearts-ease, joy and mirth.
And heaven at last, after long life on earth.

sp.speaker: pol,
sp.l: Her counsel wise, and Nobles of this land
Bless, and preserve O Lord with thy right hand.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.l: On all the rest that in this Land do dwell,
Chiefly in London, Lord pour down thy grace,
Who living in thy fear and dying well,
In heaven with Angels they may have a place.
